loans.name: Sheroz

texts.en:
A. Sheroz is a young, energetic man. From the early age of 18, he started his own business in order to support his parents. His business is selling home products in the famous market of Khujand city, “Panjshanbe”. This business allows him not only to support his family household but also to continue his University education.  Sheroz needs to increase the variety of goods he sells and is asking for a loan of $ 800 USD with a term of 9 months. This loan will allow him to expand his business and earn more income. This loan will be an important part in the growth of Sheroz’s business.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy various home products for resale

loans.name: Abdurahim

texts.en:
Abdurahim is an active client of IMON International. He has a little shop with a refrigerated case for meat and dairy products. He became a client of IMON International in 2006 and used his first loan to purchase his first batch of meat products like sausages, boiled sausage, frankfurter, etc. The business was successful, and Abdurahim decided to conclude an agreement with a distribution firm for a longterm partnership. 

Today his shop is one of the known shops in the food market. He is a very cheerful person, and he is always glad to meet anyone who comes into his shop. All his clients are satisfied with his service. Abdurahim tries to make his assortment of food products more competitive. In the near future he dreams of expanding his business and buying another refrigerated case. Right now, however, he is requesting $ 1000 USD to purchase sausages, boiled sausage, frankfurter, butter and cheese. This loan will be an important part of the growth of Abdurahim’s business.

loans.use: To purchase sausages, boiled sausage, frankfurter, butter and cheese.

loans.name: Tanzania Group

texts.en:
Kapembe H., age 35, is married with two children ages 14 and 12. She has a beauty salon which she started 6 years ago and works daily from 8 am until 8 pm. She is able to earn a monthly income of around $387. 

This will be Kapembe’s third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase the stock of her salon and started a kiosk where she sells cold drinks and snacks. Kapembe has repaid these loans successfully. She now hopes for a third loan to increase her kiosk business. 
	
Kapembe will share this loan with her loan group, Tanzania, which totals 18 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Kapembe is in the centre, sitting on a chair.

loans.use: To buy cold drinks and snacks for resale.

loans.name: Umri

texts.en: H. Umri is 48-years old and the loving mother of three children. The elder son is already a student and the younger children are starting school. Umri and her husband dream  that their children will have a higher education. She sells meat products like sausages, boiled sausage, frankfurter, and dairy products such as cheese, butter, mayonnaise, etc. She has been in this business for 5 years. Umri is a very polite and cheerful woman by her nature. She has regular customers who buy in bulk, which allows her to have a stable income for her family. Umri is requesting a loan of $ 1000 USD. She is planning to purchase a greater variety of meat products in order to meet her client’s demands. She expects to repay the loan in 12 months. Umri sincerely thanks all the lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy meat products and provide a greater variety of goods.

loans.name: Namutamala Lending Group

texts.en: Esther K., age 60, is the chairperson of the Namutamala lending group in Mpigi. Ten years ago she was one of the founding members of her group. She has operated a business since 1989, keeping animals (cows) at her home and poultry, for the last for 4 years. In total, she has 3 cows that provide her with milk for sale and 100 laying hens that very soon will be laying  eggs. These hens are replacement of those that she had sold. She is requesting a loan to purchase more laying hens to expand her business. As a result of investing more in her business, Esther has been able to save  money which has helped her with buying household items as well as making life comfortable for her orphaned grand children. Esther is a widow with 7 children. Most of her children have passed away and left her with the care of the grandchildren that she has to work so hard to provide for. She is grateful for the loans as she has been able to stock chicken feeds and medication for her animals. This would not have been possible without the loans. She is really a hardworking elderly lady that does farming on a very small scale mostly for food to feed her grandchildren.

loans.use: To buy more laying hens and chicken feed to expand a business.

loans.name: Baroat

texts.ru: Бароат кредитор в Микроинвест уже пятый год.Она пунктуально работает с нами.Её ассортимент товара детская одежда.Она хочет пополнить свой товар зимней детской одеждой и обувью.Бароат благодарна за финансирование всем инвесторам.Её бизнес увеличился во много раз благодаря кредитам.
texts.en:
Baroat has been a client of MicroInvest for the past five years, and she makes her payments on time. She has an assortment of children's clothing, and hopes to expand her line of children's winter clothing and shoes. Baroat is grateful to all the investors for their financial assistance. Thanks to these loans, her business has grown many times over.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Children's Clothes

loans.name: Twebaze Lending Group

texts.en: B. Solome is the chairperson of the Twebaze lending group in Jungo. She is 40 years old, married and has 7 children, all attending school. She also cares for 2 orphan children belonging to her late brother, including paying their school fees, clothing, medical care and general upkeep. Solome has a retail shop business that she has been running for over 5 years. The loans have been used to re-invest into her business, enabling her to buy more stock in her shop like sugar, soap, cooking oil, salt, maize flour, etc The profits she earns are used for her children's school fees. Solome's husband is a farmer. He sells his harvests locally as well as at the large farmers market in Kibuye. Solome is requesting a loan to help her with restocking her shop in preparation for the beginning of the school term which is next month.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with sugar, salt, maize flour and other products.

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.ru: Мавлюда заёмщица с 2004 года.Она все эти годы хорошо без проблем погашала свои кредиты.Вначале своего бизнеса она продавала носки, но постепенно увеличив кредит она заменила ассортимент на детскую одежду.Мавлюда недавно стало бабушкой для третьего внучка.Она счастливая мать и бабушка в своей семье.Мавлюда с радостью получает свой очередной кредит для увеличения ассортимента детской обуви.Её фото во время выдачи.
texts.en:
Mavluda has been a borrower since 2004 and has always repaid her loans without a glitch. She started her business with selling socks and, by gradually increasing her credit, replaced her goods assortment with children’s clothing. Mavluda recently became a grandmother for the third time and is a happy mother and grandmother in her family. Mavluda would be pleased to obtain this loan in order to increase the assortment of children’s shoes.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of children's shoes

loans.name: Agwi Celine

texts.en:
Celine is married to Mbah Roland and they are have three children, two of whom are below 15 years of age. Celine has worked hard to support these children, but along the way she has encountered some challenges such as the death of two children and a young daughter who had a child out of wedlock. Because of these challenges, life became difficult for her until she saw GHAPE as a source of relief in the year 20004. in that year she received her first loan of 20,000 FRS,then 60,000 FRS in 2005 and 150,00 FRS in 2006. 

Celine is now requesting a loan of 150,000 FRS so she can buy tomatoes, beans, spices, and so forth. She is convinced the business will succeed because of her long experience in the business, and she already has a ready market for her goods. She plans to use the profit from the loan to pay for her children's school fees and to cloth them. This business helps her community by supplying food locally, reducing the distance people need to travel to buy food. 
	
Celine prefers to receive loans from GHAPE because of the training GHAPE provides before disbursing loan and the follow up GHAPE provides after the loan is disbursed.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and the alleviation of poverty through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Nih Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is married to Elizabeth Bih and they are blessed with three children, all of them above 15 years of age. Patrick and his entire family are living in a house with three bedrooms and one sitting room. As a very hard working man, Patrick has faced many challenges in life. In the process of struggling to earn a living, he encountered many challenges in life such as the death of his pigs and people owing him huge sums of money for work done. These problems made life very difficult for him until 2005 when he became a member of GHAPE and received his first loan (for 20,000 FRS). He received a loan of 65,000 FRS in 2006 and 400,000 FRS in 2007. He successfully repaid these loans. 

Now Patrick is requesting a loan so he can buy “wilberoo" fish and five piglets and make repairs on his pig pen. Repayment of the loan will start at the fourth month from the day of disbursement. Patrick is convinced that the business will succeed because of the experience he has had in it and he is well known in the community as fish supplier.

Patrick plans to use the profit from the loan to construct a good house for his family, pay for his children's school fees, and to feed and cloth his family. He prefers a loan from GHAPE because of the training GHAPE provides before giving out loans and the follow up it does after the loan is disbursed to ensure  proper usage of the loan.

Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy fish and pigs

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married to Wulie Vincent. They have six children, four of whom are below 15 years of age. Margaret is living with her entire family in a house with three sleeping rooms and one sitting room. Margaret has faced many challenges in life, which made life difficult for her. But in 2006, she became a member of GHAPE and obtained her first loan, which was for 20,000 FRS. She obtained a second loan in 2008 (for 150,000 FRS), and she repaid both loans promptly.

Now Margaret is requesting a loan of 300,000 FRS so she can buy fruits and vegetables such as yams, plantains, cocoyams, pineapple, carrots, and banana. 

Margaret greatly believes her business will succeed because of the experience she has had in this business and because her goods are in high demand. This business helps Margaret’s community by supplying food locally, reducing the distance people need to travel to buy food. She plans to use the profit from the loan to pay for her children’s school fees and to feed and cloth her children. Her repayments will commence at the fourth month from the day of disbursement.
	
Margaret prefers to receive loans from GHAPE because of the training GHAPE provides before disbursing loan and the follow up GHAPE  provides after the loan is disbursed.

GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ngwe

texts.en:
P. is happily married, and she has been blessed with five children, two of whom are below 15 years of age. P. is living with her entire family in a house with four sleeping rooms and one sitting room. P. has faced many challenges in life—such as the death of a child, school dropouts, and family problems. These problems made life unpleasant for P.. But in 2006, P. became a member of GHAPE, and obtained her first loan, which was for 20,000 FRS. In 2008, she obtained a loan of 150,000 FRS. She repaid both loans promptly.
	
Now P. is requesting a loan of 300,000 FRS so she can buy yams, plantains, cocoyams, pineapples, carrots, and bananas.
           
P. greatly believes her business will succeed because of the experience she has had in the business and because her goods are in high demand. With this  business, P. will help her community by supplying food to them locally and reducing the distance they have to go to buy their food. She plans to use the profit from the loan to pay for her children’s school fees and to feed and cloth her children. Her repayments will commence at the fourth month from the day of disbursement.
	
She prefers to receive loans from GHAPE because of the training GHAPE offers before disbursing loans and the follow up GHAPE  provides after the loan is disbursed.

Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Shabana Ishtiaq Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Shabana baji is a 32 -year-old married lady and resides in a city called Borewala, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 20 years. She is an uneducated lady. She couldn’t attend school because the school was far away from her house and there were no conveyances to reach the school. She got married at the age of 17 to a person whose name is I. A. who is a driver, driving a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

Shabana baji is the mother of three daughters. Her eldest daughter is in 9th standard. Another is in 4th standard. Her youngest daughter is in kindergarten. Shabana baji is a very responsible woman. She wishes to give her daughters everything she didn’t get in her life. She and Mr. I. A. decided to share the financial burden of supporting their family. So she takes the responsibility for her daughters' education and her husband takes the responsibility for household expenses. Shabana baji successfully repaid her first two loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institution in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy a new auto-rickshaw for her husband.

Shabana baji is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Zubaida S. baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Sabri baji wants a loan to buy milk to re-sell. Samina H. baji wants a loan to buy vehicle wheels to re-sell. Nazia baji wants a loan to buy mobile phones for her mobile phone shop. Noreen baji wants a loan to repair her 32-seater bus called “Coaster”.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Razia Atah Muhammad Group

texts.en:
Razia baji is a 43-year-old married lady and resides in a city named Borewala, Pakistan. She has lived here with her family for the last 30 years. Her husband's name is A. M., and he is a mason with 20 years of experience. Razia baji is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. Her elder son drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Another is a cobbler and makes shoes. Her younger son reads in 5th standard (at 5th grade level). Her elder daughter reads in 9th standard and her younger daughter reads in 2nd standard. Razia baji is a seamstress and sews clothes. She does both this tailoring work and her household work. Her family honors her by taking care of themselves. She sews clothes to share the financial burden of her husband. She successfully repaid her previous two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan and a Kiva Field Partner). Now she is applying for a loan to buy masonry tools for her husband.

Razia baji is a group leader of four other women from her locality. Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy more clothes to resell. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Bilquis baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy masonry tools for a husband's business; clothes, groceries, and scrap to sell; and an auto-rickshaw.

loans.name: Veronica Ngeh

texts.en:
Veronica is married to Fusi and they are blessed with two children, one of whom is below 15 years of age. She has faced many challenges in life--such as ill health, the death of two of her children, and divorce. Faced with all these challenges, life was not comfortable for Veronica. Veronica learned about GHAPE in 2007, and she is now able to take good care of her children.

In 2007, Veronica received her first loan (40,000 FRS) and she repaid it promptly. With this loan of 200,000 FRS, she plans to construct a pig fence; rent a plot of land for cultivation; and buy firewood, vegetable seeds, and fertilizer.

Veronica is sure this business will succeed because of the experience she has in this area, because the demand for the vegetables she is producing is high in her locality, and because she is trusted by the people in her community. Veronica will help those in her community by providing vegetables and firewood to them. She plans to use the profit from the loan to pay for her children’s school fees and to complete her house. Veronica plans to start repayment on the same day of disbursement.

Veronica prefers to receive a loan from GHAPE because of the rules and regulations governing the institution and because of the follow up that GHAPE does after the loan is disbursed, to ensure the loan is not misused.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and the alleviation of poverty through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: vegetable cultivation, pig farming, and sale of firewood

loans.name: Rehana Kosar M. Saleem Group

texts.en:
Rehana Kosar baji is a 26-year-old married lady and resides in a city called Borewala, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 20 years. Her husband's name is M. S. and he is a driver, driving a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). She is the mother of two kids: one son and one daughter. Both of her children are in kindergarten.

Rehana Kosar baji stays at home and sews clothes for her neighbors. She does this work to earn income. She invests her income in a committee and plans to renovate her house when it's her turn to get the amount. She is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for her husband. That way, he will be able to keep all of his hard-earned income.

Rehana baji is the group leader for some more woman from her locality. Naseema Shaheen baji wants a loan to buy paint for her paint shop. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Che

texts.en:
I. is married to Che John and they are blessed with five children, two of whom are below 15 years of age. I. lives with her entire family in a house with six sleeping rooms and one sitting room. I. has had to work hard her whole life just to sustain the life of her family. I. has encountered some challenges in life such as the death of her husband and poor health. These challenges made life miserable for I. until she discovered GHAPE in 2007 and became a member.
	
In 2007, I. received her first loan (40,000 FRS) and she repayed it on time. With this loan of 200,000 FRS, she plans to buy palm oil for 100,000 FRS, and firewood for 75,000 FRS. The remaining 25,000 FRS will be used for transportation of the goods she buys. 
	
I. is convinced the business will succeed because of the experience she has had in this area. Furthermore, she is well known in her locality as the main supplier of these goods, and the members of her community trust her. I. plans to use the profit from her loan to pay for her children's school fees, to feed them, and to take of their medical needs. I. prefers to received loans from GHAPE because of the trust she has for GHAPE, and because the method of repayment is comfortable and convenient.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and the alleviation of poverty through a highly multi-faceted approach. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy of palm oil and firewood

loans.name: Khalida Parveen Muzaffar Hussain Group

texts.en:
Khalida Parveen baji is a 35-year-old married lady and resides in a city called Borewala, Pakistan. She has lived here with her family for the past 15 years. Her husband's name is M. H. and he is a delivery man, delivering different items, specifically fruits and vegetables, from the wholesale market to various shops. Khalida baji is the mother of four kids: two sons and two daughters. Her elder son is in 9th standard and her younger son is in 2nd standard. Her elder daughter is in 5th standard and her younger daughter is in 3rd standard.

Khalida baji has a knitting business. She knits tablecloths and sofa covers and then sells them in cloth markets. People from her community buy them and give her orders as well. Her income allows her a confident and independent life. She is very happy that she is striving to improve the living standard of her family. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institution in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy a new donkey cart because their previous cart is in bad condition.

Khalida baji is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Zahida Parveen baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her fruit-selling business. Samina baji wants a loan to buy cigarettes to re sell. Asmat baji and Sajida baji each want a loan to change the body of their auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Najma baji wants a loan to buy utensils to re-sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart to carry loads

loans.name: Anastazia

texts.en: Anastazia L. is a Tanzanian woman entrepreneur. She runs a clothing shop. She makes and sells a variety of clothes, including traditional clothing, to customers. Her business is located in Vituka in Dar es Salaam. Anastazia has been in this business for three years. Income generated from the business is used to meet her daily family needs. She requests a loan of Tshs 800,000 to meet her business demand.

loans.use: To buy more clothing items to expand her business

loans.name: Siddiqa Ghulam Haider Group

texts.en:
Siddiqa baji is a 43-years-old married lady and resides in a city called Borewala, Pakistan. She is the mother of three children: one son and two daughters. Her son works in a factory. Her elder daughter is in 8th standard and her younger daughter is in 5th standard. Siddiqa baji’s husband's name is G. H. and he drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Siddiqa baji has a sewing business. She sews clothes for her neighbors and earns income. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institution in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to change the body of the auto-rickshaw of her husband.

Siddiqa baji is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Zareena baji and Jamila baji and another Jamila baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy vehicle wheels to re-sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To change the body of their auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Zahida Abdul Latif Group

texts.en:
Zahida baji is a 40-year-old married lady and resides in a small area called Riwind in the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She is an uneducated lady and she doesn’t get hesitate to mention that this is the case because she belongs to a poor family and her parents couldn’t cover her education expenses. She married a man whose name is A. L. who is a driver, driving an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). She has six children: four sons and two daughters. Her eldest son also a driver, driving a rented auto-rickshaw. Her others kids are getting education from a school which is located near their house.

Zahida baji is involved in a decorative embroidery business. She makes embroidered dresses and sells them at clothing markets. She gets US$ 3 per dress. She invests the income in a committee and plans to renovate her house when it is her turn to get the amount. She is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her son.

Zahida baji is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy vegetables for her vegetable-selling business. Farzana baji wants a loan to buy sewing machines for her clothes-sewing business. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy scraps for her scrap business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Ngwa

texts.en:
M. is married to Ngwa Florence Ngum and they have four children, three of whom are below 15 years of age. M. works hard to sustain the life of his family. He has encountered some challenges, such as ill health, lack of basic commodities to earn a living, and having to drop out of school. These challenges made life miserable for M. until 2006 when he learned aboout GHAPE and became a member.
	
M. received a loan of 20,000 FRS from GHAPE in 2006, and 200,000 FRS in 2007. He repaid these loans promptly.
		
With this loan, M. plans to buy piglets for 100,000 FRS, construct the pig pen for 50,000 FRS and buy fowls for 100,000 FRS. He is convinced the business will progress because of the experience he has had in the business, and because he already has a ready market for his products. His business will provide alternative sources of protein to his community.
	
He will start repaying the loan in the fourth month after he receives the money. He plans to use part of the the profit from the business to plow back in to his business, and part of it to pay for his children’s school fees.  M. prefers to receive loans from GHAPE because of the training GHAPE offers before disbursing loans and the follow up that GHAPE does to ensure the loan is properly managed.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and the alleviation of poverty through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy  piglets and fowls

loans.name: Parveen M. Ashraf Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is a 40-year-old married lady and resides in a small area named Riwind in the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has lived there with her family for the past 40 years. Her husband's name is M. A. and he has an animal-selling business. He has 15 years of experience in this business. He buys the animals from animal markets and sells them to butcher shops, earning a profit.

Parveen baji is the mother of five kids: three daughters and two sons. Her sons are enrolled in a school which is located near their house. Parveen baji embroiders shoes. She learnt this art from her mother and now this skill gives her a reward in the form of money. Parveen baji has passed on this art to her daughters as well. The order she used to complete in 15 days, with the help of her daughters she now completes in one week. She feels very proud of her daughters. She is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s animal-selling business by buying more animals.

Parveen baji is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Meena baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her fruit-selling business. Ayesha baji wants a loan to buy raw materials (leather and nails) for her shoemaking business. Shabana baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats) for her animal-selling business. Majidan baji wants a loan to buy a power loom to manufacture clothes to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals for their animal-selling business

loans.name: Suzana

texts.en: Suzana K. is a Tanzanian business woman and entrepeneur. She runs a business supplying milk to customers. She sells milk supplied from her own farm and purchases additional supplies of milk directly from other farmers which she then transports to her customers. Her customers include restaurants, cafes, and families. She requests a loan of Tshs 600,000 to increase her own farms milk supply.

loans.use: Increasing milk supply and expanding business

loans.name: Hanifan Maqbool Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Hanifan baji is a 32-year-old married lady and resides in a small area called Riwind in the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She has lived in this city with her family for the past 32 years. She married a man whose name is M. A.. He is involved in a catering business with an experience of 15 years.

Hanifan baji is the mother of four kids: two sons and two daughters. None of her children goes to school. Hanifan baji has been a midwife for the past 15 years. She invests the profits from her work in a committee and plans to renovate the house when it is her turn to receive the amount. She is applying for a loan to buy furniture and table covers and chair covers for her husband’s catering business.

Hanifan baji is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Parveen baji and Kosar baji and Sobia baji each want a loan to buy seasonal fruit for their fruit-selling businesses. Razia baji wants a loan to buy raw materials (leather and nails) for her shoemaking business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy furniture etc. for catering business

loans.name: Mwasiti

texts.en: Mwasiti H. is a business woman and entrepreneur in Tanzania. She lives on Kigamboni Island in Dar es Salaam. She is the mother of four children, two of which are in secondary school and two are in primary school. Her ability to pay her children's school fees and provide for her household expenses depends on the income she can generate from her small business. For the past six years she has run a cafe in Kigamboni. She requests a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to buy more food items to meet the needs of her cafe's customers.

loans.use: Buy more food items and expand cafe business

loans.name: Saboat

texts.en: Saboat M. is 29 years old and lives with her spouse. She works every day, starting very early in the morning so that she can succeed and achieve her goal of having her 2 children successfully finish school and enter University. Her business is located in the central market of Istaravshan town and she sells clothes for women. With the support of her spouse and her own effort, she was able to expand her business. A business that began with little inventory and in a small space, now has much more space with a large clientele. With the loan of 3000 Somoni ($ 900 USD), which she will repay in 5 months, she will buy a greater variety of clothing styles, for a variety of occasions, including a few special requests from her customers.Saboat has the strength and courage to make her business a success and thanks kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: Purchase women's clothing in order to increase the variety of goods for sale.

loans.name: Zareena M.hanif Group

texts.en:
Zareena baji is a 52-year-old married lady and lives in a small area called Riwind in the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She is an uneducated lady and she doesn’t hesitate to mention that she comes from a poor family and her parents couldn’t cover her education expenses. Her husband's name is M. H. and he is a farmer. She is the mother of five sons. Her eldest son has a fruit-selling business. The others work in a factory for monthly wages. Zareena baji belongs to a decorative embroidery business. She makes embroidered dresses and sells them in clothing markets, charging US$ 3 per dress. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruit to expand her son’s fruit-selling business.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Nusrat baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart to transport loads. Nabila baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, cooking oil, and spices) for her food-selling business. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy a bicycle to re-sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruit for fruit-selling business

loans.name: Oulimata

texts.fr: Oulimata B., 33 ans, célibataire, 05 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Boucotte Peyrissac depuis 7 ans et demi. Elle veut acheter des robes et des tissus pour renforcer son activité de vente d’habillement. Oulimata participe à la prise en charge de sa famille Le prêt qu'elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Oulimata B. is 33 years old, single and has five children. She has been in charge of the village bank loan group of Boucotte Peyrissac village for the past seven and a half years. She would like to buy some dresses and fabrics to support her clothing sales business. Oulimata is responsible for meeting the family's expenses. The loan that she is requesting will be paid back in a single lump sum payment at the end of the six month term.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase dresses and fabrics for resale.

loans.name: Yasmeen M.younas Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen baji is 27 years old and married. She has lived in a small area named Riwind in the city of Kasur, Pakistan. Her husband's name is M., and he is an electrician by profession. Yasmeen baji is the mother of two sons. Neither of her children goes to school. Yasmeen baji’s brother also lives with her. He is a goldsmith and makes gold jewelry. He has 20 years of experience in this business. Yasmeen baji is applying for a loan to buy jewelry-making tools to expand her brother’s gold business.

Yasmeen baji is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Rani baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit-selling business. Shakeela baji wants a loan to buy salt to resell. Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for her clothes-making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy jewelry-making tools for a brother's business, a sewing machine, and seasonal fruits and salt to resell.

loans.name: Bahrom

texts.en: S. Bahrom is 48 years old and has a secondary school education. He is married and has 4 children. Bahrom has been farming for 10 years and learned this occupation from his father. He plants wheat on his farmland. Bahrom will use his loan to fertilize his land and to purchase seeds for planting. After the harvest, local residents will be able to purchase wheat at a lower price than they would pay at the market. They will use the wheat to make flour and bread. Bahrom will pay back the loan over 12 months and thanks everyone for supporting him. This loan will assist him in providing for his family.

loans.use: To purchase fuels, lubricants, seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Amabo

texts.en:
Born January 25, 1942, Pa Amabo J. is married to Ma Helen Ngum.  They have been blessed with eight children, two of whom are still below the age of fifteen. Amabo and his family live in a seven-room apartment in the Ntaghem neighborhood of Nkwen.

Due to circumstances beyond his control, Amabo didn’t have the privilege of basic education or an apprenticeship to learn a trade, because his parents where poor. Even worse, both his parents died when he was still very young because they did not have money to pay for medication. Amabo joined GHAPE on October 8, 2003. Since then, he has borrowed and successfully repaid four loans and the profits from these loans have helped him to sustain his life and that of his family, as well as to provide for the school needs of his younger children.
	
With this loan of 500000frs, he plans to buy piglets, pig feed, wood, and fish to resell from his home so as to reduce the distance that his neighbors must trek to obtain these items. He will use part of the profit generated by this loan to continue to educate his children and part will be reinvested in his business. He thinks his business will succeed because he has been doing this business for a long period of time.

Amabo will start repaying the loan in the fourth month after he receives the loan.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and the alleviation of poverty through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy piglets, feed , wood, and fish

loans.name: Safia Rahmat Ali Group

texts.en:
Safia baji is 56 years old and married. She owns a two-room brick house in a city named Vehari, Pakistan and has lived in it with her family for the last 25 years. She is an uneducated lady. She could not get an education due to few financial resources and the sudden death of her father. Her father passed away when she was just 5 years old. Her husband's name is R. A., and he has a business selling cane products. He makes cane furniture and ladders as well and sells the products in markets. He has 40 years of experience in this business. They have four sons. The first two sons are involved in a sewing machine repair business. The younger sons are involved in their father’s business. Safia baji also helps her husband in cleaning the cane sticks. She successfully repaid her previous two loans that she took from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan and Kiva Field Partner). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy more cane sticks to expand her husband’s business.

She is the group leader of three other women. Irshad baji wants a loan to buy vehicle engine oil to resell. Sabran baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. Hafizan baji wants a loan to buy washing powder to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy cane sticks for making furniture, engine oil to resell, beams for a shutter business, and powdered soap to resell.

loans.name: Shamshad M.aslam Group

texts.en:
Shamshad baji is 30 years old and married. She owns a two-room brick house in a city named Vehari, Pakistan and has lived in it with her family for the last 25 years. She is an uneducated lady. She could not get an education because her parents could not provide one for her with their little financial resources. Her husband's name is M. A.. He has a business selling sewing machines and 10 years of experience in this business. Shamshad baji is the mother of two sons who are not yet school-age. She performs her duties as a mother and as a wife also. Her dream is to see her sons in good positions. To achieve her dream, she makes embroidered dresses and sells them in clothes markets. She does this work because her parents could not provide her other education or training, but she wants to give skills and opportunities to her kids. She successfully repaid her first loan that she took from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan and Kiva's Field Partner). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy more sewing machines to increase her husband’s income.

She is the group leader of three other women. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy another motorbike for her motorbike rental business. Saleema baji wants a loan to buy utensils for her utensils-selling business. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy sewing machines for her business selling sewing machines.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy sewing machines and utensils to resell, and to buy a motorbike to rent out.

loans.name: Majidan M. Yousaf Group

texts.en:
Majidan baji is 38 years old and married. She resides in a city named Vehari, Pakistan. She has lived here for the last 20 years. Her husband's name is M. Y.. He has a business selling sewing machines. Majidan baji is the mother of three kids: two sons and one daughter. None of her children goes to school. Majidan baji has a business making and selling warm quilts. She has 16 years of experience in this business. She learned this art from her mother. Now this art is helping her to improving the living standard of her family. She saves her income to admit her children in a school so that they can be educated and get good positions in their careers. She successfully repaid her previous two loans of Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan and Kiva Field Partner). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy material (cloth, cotton and thread) to increase the profit of her quilt-making business.

Majidan baji is the group leader of three other women. Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, cotton and thread) to increase the profit of her business. Kosar mai baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to resell. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy sewing machines to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for a quilting business and fertilizer and sewing machines to resell.

loans.name: Shahida Parveen Group

texts.en:
Shahida parveen baji is 26 years old, married and resides in a the city of Vehari, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has lived there with her family for the past 20 years. She has no formal education but never hesitates to join a conversation as she has good talking manners. Her husband, M. H. has been in the dried fruit selling business for 10 years. He buys dried fruits from places called “Murree and Chitral”. These places are famous for their dried fruits. Shahida baji has one son who is just 4 days old. She stays at home, does household work and in addition, sews clothes as a business. She sews clothes at home, taking orders from her neighbors. She saves her income in a village bank and plans to renovate her house when she finally saves enough.. She is applying for a loan to buy dried fruit to expand her husband’s dried fruit selling business. 

Shahida baji is a leader of a women's loan group. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Qadeer Ilahi baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her drug store. Begum safia T. baji wants a loan to buy stationary (pencils, razors and notebooks) to resell. Bhoori baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy dried fruits to resell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret E. is 44 years old and married with 7 children. She sells plantain in wholesale and retail to her customers. She plans to expand her plantain business so she can make more profit. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 to purchase more plantain to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more plantain to sell

loans.name: Manzooran Khalil Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Manzooran baji is 33 years old, married, and resides in the city of Vehari, Pakistan. She has lived with her family for the past 5 years. Her husband, K. A. is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) and has 20 years experience. Manzooran baji is a mother of four children: three daughters and one son. Her son works in a grocery shop as a salesman and earns a monthly wage. Her daughters help her in her clothes sewing business. She teaches them how to cut and shape a dress and how to sew it. Now her first two daughters are trained and they can sew clothes easily by themselves. Manzooran baji feels very pleased to watch them work. This work gives herself and her daughters a good income. She is applying for a loan to repair her husband’s auto-rickshaw. 

Manzooran baji  is also the leader of a women's loan group. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Shahida mai baji wants a loan to buy another motorbike for her motorbike rental business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Maryam Rab Nawaz Group

texts.en:
Maryam baji is 50 years old, married, and resides in the city of Vehari, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has lived there, with her family for the past 20 years. She is a mother and has two sons. Both of her sons have completed their bachelors degree. Her elder son works in a government office named WAPDA. Another runs his own tuition center. Maryam baji’s husband is retired and spends most of his time in house. She is a seamstress and sews clothes for her neighbors and earns an income. She saves her income in a village bank group and plans to use it to marry off her eldest son. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy furniture for her younger son’s tuition center, because by the grace of God his center is going well and requires additional furniture (chairs and tables). 

Maryam baji is the leader of a women's loan group. Haleema baji and Ameer baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops. Nadia ashraf baji wants a loan to buy motorbikes spare parts to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy furniture for a tuition center

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase seed, plant cuttings, manure, and fuel oil.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy A. sells kitchen utensils and household items at the Uselu Market in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. She is 38 years old and is married with 3 children. She travels to Onitsha to purchase the goods that she sells in Benin City. 

She needs a loan of N30, 000 to purchase more kitchen utensils and household items to sell. She says "thank you" to everyone who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more household items and kitchen utensils to sell

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina E. sells women's clothes and shoes. She is 32 years old and is married with 12 children. Her husband is a commercial driver. 

Paulina purchases her goods in Onitsha and Lagos. She is from Edo State, Nigeria. She needs a loan of N30,000 to purchase more clothes and shoes to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Making fufu (porridge) from cassava is one trade that is lucrative for Justina A.. She has been working in this business for some time now. She is married with 5 children and she is forty years old. Her children are in secondary and primary school. They also help her when they are free. 

She purchases her cassava from the village market and takes them to the city to mill them and get the fufu out of them. Justina needs a loan of N30000 to purchase more cassava to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava  to sell

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith N. is 45 years old and is married with 4 children. Her two eldest children just graduated from the University of Benin. She owns a restaurant where she sells cooked foods and drinks. 

She needs a loan of N30000 to purchase more food and drinks to cook and sell. She says "thank you" to everyone who has made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more food and drinks to cook and sell

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen es socia del Banco Comunal Inti que quiere decir Sol en quechua.
Carmen es conviviente, tiene 27 años y 1 hijos, Carmen junto a su esposo tienen un taller de planchado y pintura en un local alquilado. Además Carmen vende repuestos en el mismo lugar, sus productos los adquiere en la ciudad de Lima.
Carmen necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de pernos, puertas, faros.
Carmen sueña con tener muchos sucursales, casa propia.
texts.en:
Carmen is a member of the Community Bank "Inti", which means sun in Quechua. Carmen lives with her husband, is 27 years old, and has 1 child. Carmen and her husband have an ironing and painting workshop in a rented space. In addition, Carmen sells spare auto parts in the same place. Her products are purchased in the city of Lima. Carmen needs a loan of 1000 soles, which will be invested in purchasing bolts, doors, and headlights. Carmen dreams of having many branches of her business and a house of their own.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bolts, doors, and headlights

loans.name: Franscisca

texts.en:
Franscisca O. sells food and groceries. She is 49 years old and is married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. 

She needs a loan of N140,000 to purchase more food and groceries to sell. She says "thanks" to everyone who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more food and groceries to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth E. sells food, drinks and groceries. Her shop is open daily from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. 

She needs a loan of N70, 000 to purchase more food, drinks, and groceries to sell. She is 42 years old and is married with 6 children. Her husband is a commercial driver. She says "thank you" to everyone who has made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more food, drinks, and groceries to sell

loans.name: Kausachun Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Kausachun que significa “Que Viva” en quechua, es un Banco que inicia su 41 ciclo con 27 socias.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como L. venta cereales, abarrotes en general, comida, frutas, fabricación D. ladrillos, leña, quesos, ferretería.
Las socias tienen diferentes historias es el caso D. Maria que es casada, tiene 44 años y 5 hijos, Marina tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes y artículos D. ferretería, también viaja a L. selva ayacuchana en donD. venD. por mayor los mismos productos, Marina necesita un préstamo D. 1050 soles dinero que invertirá en L. compra D. clavos D. diferentes tamaños.
Por otro lado Herlinda es conviviente, tiene 24 años y 2 hijos, Herlinda vive en L. comunidad D. Compañía en donD. tiene una tienda, venD. verduras, abarrotes, carnes. Herlinda necesita un préstamo D. 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. arroz, azúcar, fideo.
Mientras que Herlinda es conviviente, tiene 36 años y 3 hijos, Herlinda tiene una tienda D. abarrotes en su casa, Herlinda necesita un préstamo D. 900 soles dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. gaseosas, arroz. 
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 300 soles, 450 soles, 750 soles y 1050 soles, haciendo un total D. 14,250 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal.
Los préstamos lo invertirán en L. compra D. azúcar, arroz,  fideo, carne, verduras, trigo, cebada, leña, leche, clavos, medicina.
Los sueños D. las socias son que sus hijos tengan una buena educación, incrementar sus negocios, ahorrar mucho y tener casa propia.
texts.en:
The Community Bank "Kausachun" which means "Que Viva" [To Live] in quechua, is a bank that is beginning its 41st cycle with 27 members. The members work in different businesses, such as selling cereals, groceries in general, food, fruit, making bricks, firewood, cheeses, and hardware stores. The members all have different stories. In Maria's case, she is married, is 44 years old and has 5 children. Marina has a store in her house where she sells groceries and hardware items. She also travels to the Ayacuchana jungle where she sells primarily the same products. Marina needs a loan of 1050 soles, which she will invest in buying nails of different sizes. On the other hand, Herlinda has a live-in partner, is 24 years old, and has 2 children. Herlinda lives in the community "Compañía" where she has a store and sells vegetables, groceries, and meats. Herlinda needs a loan of 1050 soles, which she will invest in buying rice, sugar, and noodles. While Herlinda has a live-in partner, is 36 years old, has 3 children, and has a grocery store in her home, she needs a loan of 900 soles, which she will invest in buying sodas and rice. The members all need loans of different amounts. Some loans are for 300 soles, 450 soles, 750 soles or 1050 soles, totaling to 14,250 soles of loans for the community bank. The loans will be used to purchase sugar, rice, noodles, meat, vegetables, wheat, barley, firewood, milk, nails, and medicine. The dreams of the members are that their children will get a good education, expand their businesses, save a lot of money, and have their own home.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, noodles, meat, vegetables, wheat, barley, firewood, milk, nails, and medicine

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria O. sells firewood. The demands for her firewood is high. Victoria is 43 years old and is married with 5 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. 

She needs a loan of N100, 000 to purchase more firewood to sell. She says "thank you" to everyone who has made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth O. is 35 years old and is married with 6 children. Elizabeth sells clothes, shoes, and bags. She has been in this business for a long time. 

She needs a loan of N50, 000 to purchase more clothes, shoes, and bags to sell. She says "thank you" to everyone who has made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more bags, shoes, and clothes to sell

loans.name: Dani Elizabeth

texts.es:
Dani es socio del Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro 
Dani es de la Oroya tiene 36 años, es conviviente tiene una niña de 6 años que esta en el jardín, Dani solo llego a estudiar hasta tercero de secundaria nos cuenta que ya desde los once años  en su colegio vendía maní confitado desde pequeña le atrajo las ventas y siempre buscaba vender algo, ella empezó a vender pescado en la puerta de su casa, pero decidió cambiar de rubro a causa de su salud ella tiene asma entonces decidió poner una bodega ya tiene mas de dos años empezó a vender golosinas, gaseosas y fue incrementando  a abarrotes. 
Dani esta solicitando un préstamo de 400 para su negocio quiere comprar mercadería como arroz, azúcar, leche etc. 
El Sueño de Dani es tener un mini marque, llevarse bien con su esposo
texts.en:
Dani is a member of the Community Bank "Mujeres del Futuro" [Women of the Future]. Dani is from la Oroya, is a 36 year-old woman with a live-in partner and a 6 year-old daughter who is in kindergarten. Dani only went to school until her third year of high school. She tells us that since she was 11, she sold candied peanuts in her high school. Since she was little, she was attracted to sales and always was looking to sell something. She began to sell fish in the door of her home, but decided to change jobs because of her health. She has asthma, and for this reason, decided to open a grocery store. She has sold sweets and sodas for more than 2 years and has expanded to sell groceries as well. Dani is asking for a loan of 400 soles for her business. She would like to buy goods such as rice, sugar, milk, etc. Dani's dream is to have a mini-market and to get along well with her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, milk, etc.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John O. is 30 years old and single. He makes furniture. The demands for his furniture is high. 

He needs a loan of N100,000 to purchase more wood to make furniture to sell. He says "thank you" to everyone who has made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more wood for making furniture to sell

loans.name: Carlos Demetrio

texts.es:
Carlos pertenece a Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro
Carlos tiene 24 años, vive en casa de sus padres, le han dado un cuarto para que viva con su esposa,  el estudio ingles y computación pero no termino por falta de dinero, el tiene un hijo de un año y dos meses  
Carlos ha trabajado desde los diez años en mil oficios ahora es chofer de una combi de la linia Real Expres él trabaja de  6de la mañana  hasta las 9 de la noche  todos los días
Carlos solicita un préstamo de 400 soles para comprar ropa de niño y venderla en el mercado de Villa el Salvador, uno de su  sueño es tener  un puesto de venta de ropa, Casarse y tener su casa propia
texts.en:
Carlos belongs to the Community Bank Mujeres del Futuro [Women of the Future]. Carlos is 24 years old and lives with his parents, who gave him a room to live in with his wife. He studied English and computing but did not finish due to a lack of money. He has a son who is a year and 2 months old. Carlos has worked since he was 10 years old in many different jobs. Now he is a van driver for the "Real Expres" line. He works from 6 in the morning until 9 at night every day. Carlos is requesting a loan of 400 soles to buy children's clothing. He will sell it in the Villa el Salvador market. One of his dreams is to have a clothing stand, to get married and have his own home.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy children's clothing

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace G. is 38 years old and married with 3 children. She sells goat meat at the Oliha market. The demand for her goat meat is very high.  She requests a loan in the amount of N100, 000 to purchase more goat meat to sell. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more goat meat to sell

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity D. is a fashion designer and she also sells sarongs. She is 36 years old and married with 2 children. Charity requests a loan in the amount of N80, 000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all who have made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Maria Aurelia

texts.es:
Maria es socia del Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro 
Es separada tiene  43 años, dos hijos de 22 y 19 años están estudiando  superior.
Hace cinco años que Maria tiene una tienda, al principio solo atendía  los sábados y domingos, ahora abre la tienda todos los días, tiene una Hija que la ayuda todos los días. Desde que la tuvieron que  operar le preocupa más su negocio,
Desde que recibe los préstamos la han ayudado bastante se siente apoyada.
Maria necesita un préstamo de 1400 dinero que será invertido en la compra  de  una puerta y la compra de un exhibidor y congeladora (de segunda) 
El sueño que tiene es construir su casa y que su negocio sea mas grande, mejorar para ayudar a sus hijos en su carrera.
texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro (Women of the Future). She is 43 years old, separated, and has two children, aged 22 and 19, who are pursuing higher education. She has had a shop for five years, which at first she only opened on weekends but now operates every day and her daughter helps her. Since she has begun running it she has had to pay more attention to the business. The loans she has received have helped her feel supported. Maria needs a loan of 1400 with which she will buy a door and a second-hand display case and freezer. It is her dream to build a home and expand her business to better help her children with their careers.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Carreón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Maria needs a loan of 1400 to buy a display case and freezer.

loans.name: Herminia Margarita

texts.es:
Herminia es socia del Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro 
Herminia es casada tiene 59 años cinco hijos   de 37, 33, 32, 30 y 25 años, cuatro de sus hijos están casados y el último está soltero.
Tiene  una pequeña tienda en su casa, empezó hace dos años, y  por las tardes en su tienda se dedica a vender comida  y   tiene una combi que la trabaja su esposo. 
Desde  que ella  recibe los préstamos, ha podido invertir en su negocio y comprar llantas para su combi y productos para su tienda.
Herminia necesita  un préstamo  de 800 soles, que los va a invertir en la compra de gaseosas, cervezas y en la compra de abarrotes para la preparación de comidas.
texts.en:
Herminia is a member of Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro (Women of the Future). She is a 59-year-old married mother of five children, aged 37, 33, 32, 30 and 25 years old, all married themselves, except the youngest. She runs a small shop out of her home, which she started two years ago. She sells food from her shop in the afternoons and she has a small van, which her husband works for her. Since she began receiving loans she has been able to invest in her business, buying tires for the van and products for her shop. Herminia needs a loan of 800 soles to buy sodas, beers, and provisions to prepare her dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Carreón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Herminia needs a loan of 800 soles to buy sodas, beers, and provisions to prepare her dishes.

loans.name: Saul Alberto

texts.es:
Saúl es socio del Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro  
Saúl es conviviente tiene 25 años dos hijos de 4 y 6 años, los dos están en el colegio.
Hace  cuatro años  se dedica  a la fabricación de muebles, trabaja solo y su taller funciona en su casa, su mercadería la vende en el parque industrial de Villa el Salvador, es proveedor de las tiendas grandes de muebles.  
Saúl necesita un crédito de 400 soles para la compra de materiales (napa picadillo) para la fabricación de los  muebles. 
El sueño de Saúl es darles lo mejor a su familia, tener un local propio que sea grande para vender sus productos que fabrico.
texts.en:
Saúl is a member of the Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro (Women of the Future). He is 25 years old, lives with his partner, and has two children, aged 4 and 6, who are both in school. For the last four years he has worked on his own building furniture and his workshop serves as his home. He sells his merchandise in the industrial park Villa el Salvador, providing the larger stores with his furniture. Saúl needs a 400 loan to buy raw materials to build more furniture. His dream is to provide a better life for his family, and to have his own locale big enough to build and sell his products.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Carreón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Saúl needs a 400 soles loan to buy raw materials.

loans.name: Las Triunfadoras De Pan Llevar Group

texts.en:
The women of the Triunfadoras de Pan Llevar are requesting a loan of 5,300 Nuevo Soles to fund their various endeavours.  The Triunfadoras (or Triumphant Leaders) are a relatively new bank: they are just completing their first year as a group together.  They meet monthly in the Saenz Peña neighborhood of Pucallpa, Peru – a bustling capital in the eastern jungle region of the country.

Many of the women sell products in the Ollada market in the Saenz Peña neighborhood.  They are requesting loans of individual amounts, but they collectively guarantee the repayment of the entire bulk loan.  The Triumphant Leaders bank members will be using the loan to fund a variety of businesses including: sales of plantains, fruits, bottled drinks, beauty products, food, vegetables and popsicles.  Each woman will repay her portion of the bulk loan within the same four month term.

The twelve bank members pictured are: Angela V. I.(s/.500), Giovana Karina G. G. (s/.500), Noemi V. R.(s/.500), Belen G. L. (s/.500), Luz Angelica C. G. (s/.300) , Patricia Tuanama I. (s/.500), Maria Estrella G. G. (s/.500) , Victoria D. D. (s/.300), Gloris M. P.(s/.500), Antonia C. C.(s/.500), Gina Ysabel C. G. (s/.400), and Sulianita G. G. (s/.300).

loans.use: To purchase supplies of plantains, fruits, bottled drinks, beauty products, food, vegetables and popsicles for resale

loans.name: Patricia Juana

texts.es:
Patricia pertenece al Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro
Ella es casada tiene 28 años  dos hijos  de 9 años y él ultima de 10 meses, el mayor va al colegio 
Empezó con el negocio de venta de productos de belleza desde hace cinco meses, vende junto a una amiga, ella trabaja todos los días,  sus clientas son sus amigas, familiares, entre otras 
Patricia necesita un préstamo de 600 soles, que será  invertido  en la compra de productos de belleza por catalogo.
Desde que esta en Finca su negocio ha mejorado, tiene mas capital ha puesto más productos en venta, tiene un buen stock, compra a un menor precio y gana algo más, del 25%.
Ella sueña con construir su casa, y  tener una pequeña tienda, bien implementada con  vitrinas para exhibir sus productos de belleza.
texts.en:
Patricia belongs to the Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro. She is 28 years old and is married with three children. Her two youngest children are ages 9 and 10 months. Her oldest child is a high school student.

She began selling beauty products five months ago. She runs her business with a friend and works everyday. Her customers include her friends and family members.

Patricia needs a loan of 600 soles, which will be invested in the purchase of beauty products via catalog. Since joining FINCA, her business has improved. She has more capital, has offered more products for sale, has a good stock and is able to purchase her products at a lower price. She is now earning 25% more profits.

She dreams of building her own home and owning a small shop, with glass cases to display her merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Patricia needs a loan of 600 soles to buy beauty products via catalog

loans.name: Milagros Roxana

texts.es:
Milagros es socia del Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro
Es conviviente tiene 29 años cuatro hijos  de 12, 10,6, y 2 dos años, los tres mayores están en el colegio.
Milagros se dedica a la venta de ropa desde hace tres años,  trabaja como vendedora ambulante, todos los viernes hace sus compras de los pedidos que le hacen.
Necesita un préstamo de 400 soles, para la compra de ropa por campaña navideña, ya tiene muchos pedidos.
Desde que recibe los préstamos le han  ayudado a aumentar su mercadería.
Sueña con poner una tienda grande, una librería en su misma casa, para el futuro de sus  hijas.
texts.en:
Milagros is a member of the Bancomunal Mujeres del Futuro. She lives with her partner and has four children, ages 12, 10, 6, and 2. The three oldest are in school.

For three years, Milagros has been selling clothing as a traveling saleswoman. Every Friday, she purchases items to fill all the orders she has received.

She is requesting a loan of 400 soles to purchase clothing for the Christmas season. She already has many orders.

From the time Milagros started receiving loans, she has been able to increase her merchandise. She dreams of starting a stationary store in her home so that she can provide for her daughters' future.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing for the Christmas season

loans.name: Yrma Susana

texts.es:
Yrma es socia del Bancomunal Niño divino 
Yrma es casada tiene 48 años tiene tres hijos 24, 21 y 20 todos estudiantes de instituto superior 
Tiene un negocio de Restauran Anticucheria SUSY, su negocio empezó hace dieciséis años atrás,  empezó vendiendo en la puerta de su casa por las noches por todo una año con la ayuda de su esposo, hasta que decidieron ocupar la sala de su casa y atender allí, con el tiempo ocupó todo el primer piso de su casa, en la actualidad cuenta con quince mesas y personal a su cargo, ella junto con su  esposo se encargan de la administración.

Solicita un préstamo de 3000 soles que los va a invertir en la compra de mesas, sillas  y compra de comestibles para su restaurante anticucheria. 
Le gusta Finca por que recibe orientación, son solidarias y recibe prestamos.
El sueño de Yrma es ampliar su negocio a un segundo piso, le gustaría trabajar tres años mas y después contratar a una persona quien administre su negocio por que le gustaría viajar.
texts.en:
Yrma is a partner of the Bancomunal Niño divino. She is 48 years old and is married with three children, ages 24, 21 and 20. All three are university students.

She is the owner of a restaurant, the Restauran Anticucheria SUSY. She started her business 16 years ago. Yrma and her husband began selling food from the doorway of their home in the evenings for a whole year, until they decided to use the living room of their house as a dining area. Over time, the business grew to occupy the entire first floor of their home. Currently, they have 15 tables and a restaurant staff. Yrma and her husband are in charge of the restaurant administration.

Yrma is requesting a loan of 3000 soles, which will be invested in the purchase of tables, chairs and groceries for the restaurant. She likes FINCA because she receives guidance, support and loans.

Yrma's dream is to add a second floor to her business. She would like to work for three more years and then hire someone to manage the business because she would like to travel.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in the purchase of tables, chairs and groceries for her restaurant

loans.name: Maria Alvina

texts.es:
Maria es socia del Bancomunal Niño Divino
Maria es del departamento de la Libertad provincia de Bolívar, su esposo murió hace cuatro años, ella tiene 38 años y tiene dos hijas de 17 y 4 años la mayor estudia en academia, sé esta preparando por que quiere ingresar a la universidad, Maria ha vendido fruta por doce años pero decidió cambiar de negocio por que la fruta mucho se malograba, hace dos años  ella alquilo un puesto en el mercado  empezó a dar desayunos, lonches y a vender ropa usada con la ayuda de su hija, Maria trabaja de 7 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche  todos los días.

Maria solicita un préstamo de Finca de 600 para invertir en compra de Cuetes, ropa usada, y alimentos para vender por fiestas navideñas, tiene dos años en Finca le gusta el compañerismo, también nos cuenta que aprendió a ahorrar. 
Uno de los sueños de Maria es tener un puesto propio en el mercado y darle una vida mejor a sus hijas y viajar a otro país
texts.en:
Maria is a partner of the Bancomunal Niño Divino. She is from the la Libertad district in the Bolivar province. Her husband died four years ago. She is 38 years old and has two daughters, ages 17 and 4. The oldest daughter is a student and would like to continue her studies at a university.

Maria sold fruit for 12 years, but decided to switch businesses because fruit rots easily. Two years ago, she rented a space in the market to serve breakfasts and snacks and sell secondhand clothing with the help of her daughter. Maria works from 7 in the morning until 8 at night everyday.

Maria is requesting a loan with FINCA of 600 soles to invest in the purchase of fireworks, secondhand clothing and food to sell during the Christmas celebrations. She has been with FINCA for two years and enjoys the feeling of camaraderie. She also says that FINCA taught her how to save money.

A few of Maria's dreams are to own her own stand in the market, provide a better life for her daughters and travel to another country.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy secondhand clothing and food

loans.name: Maria Del Rosario

texts.es:
Maria es socia del Bancomunal Niño Divino 
Maria es separada tiene seis hijos de 33, 30, 28, 21,18, casados y él ultima de 17 años que vive con ella esta en la escuela, ella se dedica al negocio de venta de juguetes y sandalias  Maria nos cuenta que se dedica al negocio de ventas hace treinta años  tenia un puesto de ferretería, pero tuvo que dejarlo por que se separo de su  esposo, se dedico a vender libros nuevos y usados con el tiempo se dedico comprar ropa usada en la parada y  venderla en provincia  como Matucana y Tornameza por las afueras de Chosica.

Maria  solicita un préstamo de 800 soles por la campaña navideña quiere comprar Juguetes y sandalias
