texts.en: Tului E., 27, is married and has four children.  She has many years experience in the plantation business. She sells to the villagers and public people two days per week. Her husband is a very good carpenter, and his work supports the family and her business as well. This is Tului's first loan with SPBD, which is her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.  She plans to purchase fertilizer, vegetable seeds, chemicals, and plastic bags for selling her plantation items.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer, vegetable seeds, chemicals, and plastic bags for selling plantation items.

loans.name: Elenoa

texts.en: Elenoa V., 36, is married and has four children.  She has many years experience in the plantation business. Her husband is working and helps run the business.  She sells to the villagers and public people three days per week. Elenoa has had two previous loans with SPBD, which are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.  She plans to purchase chemicals, pesticides, fertilizers, and vegetable seeds for maintaining the good growth of her plantation business.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, pesticides, fertilizers, and vegetable seeds for plantation business

loans.name: Folole

texts.en: Folole T., 38, is married and has six children.  She has many years experience in selling shop stocks to the villagers and public people six days per week.  Her husband is also working, and he helps out with the family and the shop business.  Folole has had three previous loans with SPBD, which are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.  She plans to purchase items to restock her shop.

loans.use: Purchase items to restock shop

loans.name: Faalaeiau

texts.en: Faalaeiau T., 24, is married and has one child.  She has many years experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public two days per week. Her husband is working and helps her out in financing the business when it is slow.  Faalaeiau has had one previous loan with SPBD, which is her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.  She plans to purchase fertilizers, weed killer, seeds, knives, and taro tops to start a taro plantation.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers, weed killer, seeds, knives, and taro tops for a taro plantation

loans.name: Taumaia

texts.en: Taumaia F., 38, is married and has five children.  She has many years experience in the pancake business. She sells to the general public and villagers three days per week. Taumaia has had three previous loans with SPBD, which are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  She plans to purchase flour, dripping, sugar, and ripe bananas for her pancake business. The rest of the loan will be used for buying timbers, cements, bricks, and nails for home improvement.

loans.use: Purchase flour, dripping, sugar, and ripe bananas for pancake business

loans.name: Matuafetalai

texts.en: Matuafetalai T. L., 36, is married and has four children.  She has many years experience selling various stock items to the villagers and general public seven days per week. Matuafetalai has had two previous loans with SPBD, which are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.  She plans to purchase items to restock her shop.

loans.use: Purchase items to re-stock shop

loans.name: Sose

texts.en: Sose L., 35, is married and has three children.  She has many years experience in the plantation business. Her husband is a very good farmer, who works very hard on the plantation.  She sells to the general public and villagers three days per week. Sose has had two previous loans with SPBD, which are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. She plans to purchase Gromoxone, sting, weedkiller chemicals, and taro tops for her plantation business.

loans.use: Purchase Gromoxone, sting, weedkiller chemicals, and taro tops for plantation

loans.name: Ray

texts.en: Ray C., 46, is married with no children.  He has many years experience in the vegetable garden business. He sells to the general public and villagers six days per week.  He is also a good florist and makes money from this talent as well. Ray has had five previous loans with SPBD, which are his only access to capital because he has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. He plans to purchase Gromoxone and sting for his vegetable garden business.  The remainder of his loan will be used for purchasing iron roofing and sacks of cement for his house.

loans.use: Purchase Gromoxone and sting for vegetable garden business

loans.name: Tafale

texts.en: Tafale Tamato, 27, is married and has two children.  She has many years experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public and villagers two days per week. Tafale has had two previous loans with SPBD, which are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.  She plans to purchase Gromoxone, sting, chemicals, and bush knives for her plantation business.

loans.use: Purchase Gromoxone, sting, chemicals, and bush knives for plantation business

loans.name: Iulia

texts.en: Iulia S., 27, is single and has no children.  She has many years experience in selling various items to the villagers and general public seven days per week. Iulia has had four previous loans with SPBD, which are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. She plans to purchase more goods for her shop.  Part of the loan will be used to purchase timbers, nails, and iron roofing to expand her shop location.

loans.use: Purchase goods for sale and timbers, nails, and iron roofing to expand shop location

loans.name: Amy

texts.en: Amy L., 28, is a widow with three children.  She has many years experience selling a variety of shop items to the villagers and public people seven days per week. Amy has had two previous loans with SPBD, which are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She plans to purchase goods to restock her shop.

loans.use: Purchase goods to restock shop

loans.name: Ane

texts.en: Ane A., 37, is married and has two children.   Her husband is working in a mechanics shop, where they get money to improve the family finances.  Ane has two years experience selling chips to the villagers, public and families five days per week. She has had three previous loans with SPBD, which are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Ane plans to purchase bananas, peanut oil, salt, plastic bags, and flavorings for her chips business.

loans.use: Purchase bananas, peanut oil, salt, plastic bags, and flavorings for chips business

loans.name: Siniva

texts.en: Siniva P., 57, is married and has one child.  Her husband is working as an electrician. Siniva has had many years experience in the plantation business. She sells to the villagers and public people three days per week. Siniva has had one previous loan with SPBD, which is her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. She plans to purchase Gromoxone, sting, chemicals, bush knives, and seedlings for her plantation business.

loans.use: Purchase Gromoxone, sting, chemicals, bush knives, and seedlings for plantation business

loans.name: Serah

texts.en:
Serah is married with five children and lives in the town of Bamenda, Cameroon.  She plans to invest this loan in her retail business.  She wants to purchase more specifically, yam, paw-paw, oranges, and pineapples.  
 
This is Serah's fifth loan from GHAPE since she joined in 2004. Serah also has an excellent site for her business located at the entrance into the main market of the town. She has seen that there is a high demand in her produce because her inventory is always fresh. Sarah  plans to strengthen her business by purchasing these items from farms located closer to town thereby reducing her transportation costs.
 
With the profits earned from this loan, Serah plans to pay for her children's school fees and other educational needs.  She also intends to buy a piece of land for herself.  She hopes this loan will improve her and her family's standard of living. She plan to repay her loan in 18 months and her first installment repayment will be done on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.
 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of produce such as paw-paw, oranges, and pineapples and vegetable for resale

loans.name: Mbonifor

texts.en:
Pa H. was born on April 4, 1955, and he is happily married to Mankah Dorothy. They have six children. Four of their children are younger than 15 years of age.

Pa H. grew up and learned driving as a profession. After a long time earning money, he bought a motor taxi, which provided his livelihood. But, on one unfortunate night, thieves stole his car. After these difficulties in life, he decided to join GHAPE.

He enrolled in GHAPE in the 2007 and has managed a single loan with no problem of repayment. Pa H. is requesting a loan of 200,000frs to buy piglets, plantains and wood and to build a fence. He will use the profit generated by this loan to continue to educate his children and part will be ploughed back into his business. 

He thinks his business will succeed because he has been doing this business for a long period of time. He plans to repay his loan in 12 months.

loans.use: To buy piglets, wood and plantains

loans.name: Abdul Zihar

texts.en:
Abdul Zihar lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with five children, and he has a small workshop in the city of Kabul. He needs a small loan for his business to become strong and to help his family live better.
 
He requested an individual loan of 50,000 afghani for a term of 12 months, and he wants to grow his business and expand. He also wants to buy necessary materials and complete his stock for his shop so he can start working hard.

He is very happy about having the opportunity for a small loan in Afghanistan and is thankful for this opportunity, especially to the Kiva lenders around the world.

loans.use: To grow his business

loans.name: Fanaka Group

texts.en:
Augustino K., 47, is a widower with one 16-year-old child.  He also takes care of his mother. He is an electrician and also sells electrical materials. He started this business two years ago and works daily from 8 a.m. until 8 p.m. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around $62. 

This will be Augustino’s fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to increase the stock of his electrical equipment and has repaid the loans successfully. He now hopes for a fifth loan to buy more stock to sell. 
\t
Augustino will share this loan with his loan group, Fanaka, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Augustino is standing in the back, first on the left.

loans.use: To buy stock for his electrical business

loans.name: Kiyam

texts.en:
M. was born in the year 1965 and is married to Kiyam Christopher. They have seven children, of which four are younger than 15 years old. 

As a very hard working lady, M. does everything possible to see that her family lives well. She has come across some challenges, such as her children not being able to go to school, early retirement of her husband from public service, the destruction of their family house by water, and the death of her elder brother when she was still very young. 

In 2007, she saw GHAPE as a source of relief and obtained her first loan of 40,000frs and was able to do her repayment promptly.

With this loan, she plans to buy two bags of rice, one bag of beans, two bags of corn, palm oil, five bags of sawdust  and 10 crates of drinks. She will use the remainder for transport. Her experience helps ensure the sustainability of the business. By so doing, she is very sure the business will progress and grow.

She will help her community by providing food and drinks to them. She will start repayment on the same day the loan is disbursed. She prefers to receive a loan from GHAPE because of the training GHAPE has given her how to manage the loan. 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount to a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy rice, beans and drinks for sale

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long C. is 61 years old and a resident of Phnom Penh City. She currently sells clothes. 

She can earn, on average, $3.80 per day and has been running her business for more than two years. She is married and has eight children: six are single and two are married and live away from the family home. 

To help meet her family's needs, two of her daughters are employed as garment workers. Her husband is a retired policeman who earns a salary of $35 a month. 

C. expects to grow her investment, and she would like to ask for a $500 loan to buy more clothes for her business activities.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Sokung

texts.en: Mrs. Sokung V. is a villager in Kaung Kang Ty Muoy village in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband, Mr. Soam Huol, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. On this plantation they face an obstacle because they do not have enough money to hire laborers to work on the field. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Sokung V. decided to ask for a loan to hire them for this purpose. She is 30 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work on her and her husband's rice and vegetable field.

loans.name: Sothim's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sothim V. is a group leader of five women who all live in Phum Por village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr. Nim Savy, is a fisherman. He now faces a small problem because he does not have enough fishnets for his fishing. Thus, Mrs. Sothim V. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fishnets for her husband's business. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan. She is 28 years old and a mother of a child who is too young to work or study because that child is seven months old.

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK (Kiva's Field Partner) has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more fishnets for her husband's business.

loans.name: Claude

texts.en:
Claude is a 54-year-old woman who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Claude has been a seamstress for 18 years. She sews clothes for woman and children. Claude requested a loan of $1000 USD from Al Majmoua to purchase fabrics and thread; she also wants to do some maintenance work on her sewing machine. This is the first time that Claude has requested a loan.
Claude hopes that the loan will help improve her condition. Her clients are her friends, family members, and neighbors. When she first started her business, she had difficulty buying merchandise. She decided on doing this business because of her creativity and her perfectionism in her work.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics and thread

loans.name: Batbileg

texts.en:
Batbileg Z. is 20 years old. He lives with his mother and his younger sister. Three years ago, his father died. He inherited a small amount of money from his father and started to run a cafe with it. 

But their living situation became untenable, and the family decided to change the business from a café to a foodstuffs store and live in the storage room (a common side benefit to owning a store rather than a cafe in Mongolia). 

Batbileg has taken out student loans before from XacBank, Kiva’s microfinance partner in Mongolia. 

Batbileg has been a diligent saver, using profits from the business to pay for his and his sister's tuition fees and to buy a Mongolian Ger –- the traditional Mongolian nomadic home -- for his family, so they could move out of the store. But now, because of those expenditures, he needs a loan to restock his store.

loans.use: To buy goods for his grocery store

loans.name: Nheu's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nheu B. is a group leader of four people who all live in Tropang Tasok village in Kampong Chhnang province. She sells firewood and can earn a little money. Her husband, Mr. Keo Hom, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Even though they try to work hard, they still earn little income to support their household. In order to improve their living, Mrs. Nheu B. decided to request a loan to buy two piglets to start a business breeding pigs. She is 37 years old and the mother of five children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school while the others are too young to work or study.

One member of this loan group has a monthly payment loan, and the other three have end-of-term loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK (Kiva's Field Partner) has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and, a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy two piglets to start a pig-breeding business.

loans.name: Vil

texts.en: Mrs. Vil L. is a villager in Tram Roneap village in Kampong Speu province. She is a farmer who cultivates rice on a plot of land to earn a living. She is a 57-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is a construction worker while the other is employed in a garment factory. Although they try to work hard, they still earn little income to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Vil L. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to start a breeding business. She hopes to increase her income by selling the cow later.

loans.use: To buy a cow to start a breeding business.

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en: Mrs. Sreymom V. was born in 1983, and she now lives in Tram Roneap village in Kampong Speu province. She is a laborer who can make a small income to support the family. Her husband, Mr. Suong Bunna, is a bodyguard who also earns a little salary to support the family. Although Mrs. Sreymom V. and her husband try to work hard, they still live in an old house in poor conditions. In to improve these conditions, Mrs. Sreymom V. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family members to live in and have a better life. Mrs. Sreymom V. is 25 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study because that child is only a year old. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To help build a new house for her family to live in and have a better life.

loans.name: Purevdorj

texts.en:
Borrower Purevdorj L. is 52 years old. He lives with his wife and his two children in the informal housing area in Ulaanbaatar. He has been selling wristwatches and wallets on the "black market" in a place called Harhorin since 2001. 

He has good reputation and long experience in his business. Now his working capital is US$ 640. He has borrowed between US$ 100 and US$ 480 15 times from XacBank and his loan history is good. 

His dream is to own a comfortable house one day. He has been a diligent saver for years, with the result that he now has a savings balance of US$ 2,400, a sum which gets him about halfway to making his dream a reality.

Rather than spend his hard-earned savings on more watches for his business, he’d like to borrow US$ 450 from Kiva lenders. His wife is a conductor on a bus (she collects people's money), but she also helps with her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy wristwatches for re-sale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Mrs. Him Y. is a villager in Ang Sandann village in Kampong Speu province. She owns a small plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Khuon Yan, is a soldier who can earn a little salary to support the family. Although they each have different businesses, they still live in poor conditions. In order to improve these conditions, Mrs. Him Y. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family. Mrs. Him Y. is 50 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is a grocer while another one is a taxi driver. The third child is a soldier, and the youngest one is attending the local school.

loans.use: To help build a new house for her family.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 30 years old. She is married, but does not have any children.

Florence is a fashion designer. She also sells tailoring materials. She designs clothes of various styles for people in her community.

She now needs a loan of N120,000 so she can purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thank you to all who will make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Sopheab

texts.en: Mrs. Sopheap S. is a farmer in Prey Mech village in Kampong Speu province. On the plantation, she faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy an ox to plow the field. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Sopheap S. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Khut Thal, sells dessert for an income.  He uses his motorbike to carry a cart to transport the dessert. Mrs. Sopheap S. is 23 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study because that child is only a year old. Her husband is presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To buy an ox to plow the field.

loans.name: Phoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Phoeun B. is a villager in Prey Mech village in Kampong Speu province. She is a farmer who has a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Khut Keo, is a laborer who can make a small income to support the family. They have nine children -- four of whom are employed in a garment factory, while another one is a construction worker, and the remaining four are attending the local school. Although Mrs. Phoeun B.’s family members have different businesses, they still live in an old house in poor conditions. In order to improve these conditions, Mrs. Phoeun B. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To help build a new house for her family.

loans.name: Sary

texts.en: Mrs. Sary O. was born in Prey Mech village in Kampong Speu province. She has a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn her living. Her husband, Mr. Eam Vy, is a palm juice collector who gathers juice to process into palm sugar and wine. Even though they try to work hard, they still earn little income which cannot support the family well. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sary O. decided to ask for a loan to buy a calf to start a cow-breeding business. She hopes to increase her income after she sells her cow. Mrs. Sary O. is 31 years old and the mother of three children, two of whO. are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is only five years old. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a calf to start a cow-breeding business.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Mao C. is a villager in Kraing Tachor village in Kampong Speu province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Phan Phang, is a bed maker. They have a child who is a laborer. Although Mrs. Mao C.’s family members have different businesses, they still earn little income to support the family, and they also live in an old house. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Mao C. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family to live in comfortably. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To help build a new house for her family to live in comfortably.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 48 years old and married with 5 children.

Elizabeth sells foodstuffs at the New Benin Market in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. The demands for her foodstuffs are high, so she wants to grow her business.

Therefore, she needs a loan of N30,000 so she can purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Mrs. Kong T. is a villager in Tbeng village in Kampong Speu province. She is a farmer who owns small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Cheun  Thuon, is a cow breeder. Because this business is going well, he wants to expand it; so Mrs. Kong T. decided to ask for a loan to buy one more cow for her husband's business. She hopes to increase her income after she sells the cow.  Mrs. Kong T. is 33 years old and the mother of six children, four of whom are attending the local school while the remaining two are too young to work or study because they are only one and four years old. Mrs. Kong T.'s husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy one more cow for her husband's breeding business.

loans.name: Thou

texts.en: Mrs. Thou P. was born in 1966 and now lives in the Tbeng Village in the Kampong Speu Province. She is a farmer who cultivates rice on a small piece of land for a living. Her husband, Mr. Seom Ol, uses a motorbike to pull a cart in order to transport firewood to re-sell. Although Mrs. Thou P. and her husband try to work hard, they still earn insufficient income to support the family, and they also live in an old house in poor conditions. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Thou P. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family. Mrs. Thou P. has six children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another one helps the father with the business. The remaining three are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a new house for her family

loans.name: Samuth

texts.en: Mrs. Samuth K. is a villager in the Tbeng Village in the Kampong Speu Province. She is a farmer who has a plot of land to cultivate rice in order to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Chhuon Sao, is a firewood seller. Although they try to work hard, they still earn insufficient income which cannot provide a better life for the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Samuth K. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family. Mrs. Samuth K. is 32 years old and the mother of four children who are all attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a new house for her family

loans.name: Success

texts.en:
Success M. is 45 years old and married with 7 children.

Success sells second hand clothes and fish. She travels to Lagos and Onitsha to purchase her goods to sell in Benin City.

She needs a loan of N50,000 so she can purchase more fish and second hand clothes to sell. She says thank you to all who will make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more fish and also second hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en: Mrs. Thorn S. is a farmer in the Tbeng Village in the Kampong Speu Province. Her husband, Mr. Thom Chin, uses a motorbike to transport firewood to re-sell. Even though they work very hard on their businesses, they still earn insufficient income to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Thorn S. is requesting a loan to buy a cow to start a breeding business. She is 52 years old and the mother of a child who helps the father’s business. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow to start a breeding business

loans.name: Sre Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Sre Mao Y. is a villager in the Taing Po Village in the Kampong Speu Province. She and her husband, Mr. Hong Mean, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice in order to earn a living. With this plantation, they gather only a little rice revenue which is not enough to support the family well. To deal with this problem, Mrs. Sre Mao Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to start a breeding business. Mrs. Sre Mao Y. is 21 years old and the mother of a one-year-old child who is too young to work or study. Her husband is presented on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow to start a breeding business

loans.name: Sun

texts.en: Mrs. Sun K. was born in 1981 and now lives in the Toek Lorng Village in the Kampong Speu Province. She has a piece of land to cultivate rice in order to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Yun Yorn, is a palm juice collector who gathers juice to process into palm sugar. In this business, he faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to buy bamboo to tie to the palm trees to climb up to gather the juice. Thus, his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy the bamboo needed for her husband's business. Mrs. Sun K. is 27 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is only five years old. Her husband is presented on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy bamboo for her husband's (palm juice collecting) business

loans.name: Tieng

texts.en: Mrs. Tieng D. is a villager in the Tapaing Khna Village in the Kampong Speu Province. She is a farmer who owns a small plot of land to cultivate rice in order to earn a living. Her husband, Soeng Lok, is a bed maker. In this business, he has a lot of demand from his customers; so Mrs. Tieng D. decided to ask for a loan to buy some equipment to make beds for her husband's consumers. Mrs. Tieng D. is 38 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom help their parents with the business while the remaining three are attending a local school, and the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is only five years old. Her husband is presented on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy some equipment to make beds for the family business

loans.name: Wumi

texts.en:
Wumi is 38 years old and married with 2 children.

Wumi has a shop where she sells children’s clothes and clothing materials. Wumi used to hawk her goods within her community. Now, with the assistance of LAPO MICROFINANCE, she has been able to rent a shop to sell her clothes. Wumi hopes to stock her shop with more goods to meet the demands of her customers.

Therefore Wumi needs a loan of N99,000 so she can purchase more children’s clothes to sell. She says thank you to all KIVA lenders and LAPO MICROFINANCE for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more children’s clothes to sell

loans.name: Phall

texts.en: Mr. Phall C. was born in 1946 and now lives in the Tapaing Khna Village in the Kampong Speu Province. He and his wife, Mrs. Kong Meth, are farmers who have a plot of land to cultivate rice in order to earn a living. Although they try to work hard on rice cultivation, they still gather only a little rice revenue which cannot support the family well. In order to improve their living conditions, Mr. Phall C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for a breeding business. He hopes to increase his income after he sells the cow. Mr. Phall C. has three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others help on their parents' plantation. His wife is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for a breeding business

loans.name: On

texts.en: Mrs. On S. is a villager in the Tapaing Khna Village in the Kampong Speu Province. She and her husband, Mr. Khlot Suon, are farmers. On their plantation, they gather only a little rice revenue which cannot support the family well. To improve their living conditions, Mrs. On S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow in order to start a cow breeding business. Mrs. On S. is 33 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are attending a local school. Her husband is presented on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow to start a cow breeding business

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah I. is 46 years old and married with five children.

Sarah sells provisions and foodstuffs. She has been in this business for many years. She hopes to expand her business.

Sarah is an LAPO client. She now needs a loan of N140,000 so she can purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana is 53 years old and married with 5 children. She is a hardworking woman and an LAPO client.

She sells kitchen utensils like pots and plates to her customers. Christiana hopes that her business will help to pull her family out of poverty.

Christiana needs a loan of N102,000 so she can purchase more kitchen utensils to sell. She says thank you to all who will make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more kitchen utensils to sell

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en:
Taiwo sells school bags, water bottles and slippers. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to expand her business so she can meet the demands of her customers.

Taiwo needs a loan of N50,000 so she can purchase more school bags and slippers to sell.

Taiwo is 49 years old and married with six children.

She says thank you to all who will make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more bags and slippers to sell

loans.name: Tinuke

texts.en:
Tinuke sells bottled water, juice and baking materials. She has been in this business since 2005.

Tinuke loves her business because it is highly profitable to her. She opens her shop daily from 8am to 6pm.

She now needs a loan of N99,000 so she can purchase more juice, bottled water and baking materials to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more juice, bottled water and baking materials to sell

loans.name: Iyiola

texts.en:
Iyiola is 35 years old and married with five children. Her eldest child is in primary school.

Iyiola sells palm and groundnut oil in both the wholesale and retail markets. She has been in this business since 2004.

Iyiola needs a loan of N99,000 so she can buy more palm and groundnut oil to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more groundnut and palm oil to sell

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana is 35 years old and married with four children.

Christiana sells juice, drinks and bottled water. She has been in this business since 2002. She is an LAPO client. She purchases her drinks, juice and bottled water from distributors to sell to her customers. She hopes to expand her business.

She needs a loan of 70,000 so she can purchase more drinks and juice to sell. She is indeed grateful to all who will make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and juice to sell

loans.name: 23- Tân Sơn, Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Loan Group 23 consists of six poor women, all of whom live in Tan Son Commune, Thanh Hoa City. Thanh Hoa City is the provincial capital of Thanh Hoa province, one of the poorest provinces in Vietnam. It is located approximately 150 kilometers south of Hanoi, the capital of Vietnam.

Mrs. Hanh is the leader of the group. She is 50 years old, married, and has two grown children (a daughter age 26 and a son age 24). As with her first loan from the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women, which was repaid on time and in full, Mrs Hanh will use this loan to buy food for resale (oil, salt, sugar, hot sauce, and so forth) and to buy the ingredients with which to make the breakfast items she sells in her market stall. 

Prior to discovering the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (TCVM), Mrs Hanh, like many of TCVM's borrowers, used to borrow money from a money lender at exorbitant rates – in this case 5,000 VND per day (~US$0.30) on a 1,000,000 VND loan (~US$63), equal to an APR of about 250%!  TCVM charges her an APR of 24%.

* Mrs. Hồng is borrowing 1,963,500 Vietnamese Dong (~ US$123) to buy a range of medicines that she will sell from her little store.
* Mrs. Sơn will use her share of the loan to buy chickens, beef, pork, and onions to cook Phở that she will sell from her small store.
* Mrs. Hải will use her share of the loan to buy vegetables that she will resell in the Nam Ngan market.
* Mrs. Đông will use her share of the loan to buy sauce that she'll sell in her store in the Nam Ngan market.
* Mrs. Hậu is borrowing money to buy wheat flour, pork, and many thing to make bread and dumplings.

loans.use: To buy food items

loans.name: Temitope

texts.en:
Temitope is 29 years old and she is single. She sells rechargeable phone cards and she also earns money making calls. She has been in this business for the past three years.

Temitope is the lady in the blue jean skirt in the picture.

She needs a loan of N50,000 so she can purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell. She says thank you to all who will make this loan possible

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Mahmud

texts.en:
Mahmud lives in Penjikent, Tajikistan. He is 43 years old, married, and has one son. Mahmud is the sole provider for his family and earns his living by raising and selling livestock. Every year he purchases young calves from local villagers, raises them for 8-9 months, and then sells the adult cows and bulls to local butchers. Today Mahmud is thinking about expanding his business, because his current earnings are not enough to provide for his family. He wants to purchase more calves and fodder. That’s why he is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni ($600 USD) for the term of 12 months. Extend your solidarity to Mahmud so that he can move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key location along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and many great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  Even today, Tajikistan is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture, and Central Asian traditions. 

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve ittheirs agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients have the opportunity to support themselves through viable businesses. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase cattle and fodder

loans.name: Mistura

texts.en:
Mistura is 34 years old and married with three children. She is an LAPO client.

Mistura sells frozen foods like chicken, turkey and fish. She has been in this business for the past two years. The demands for her frozen foods are high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers by expanding her business.

Mistura needs a loan of N140,000 so she can purchase more frozen foods to sell. She says thanks to all who will make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is 32 years old and married with seven children. She is a hair stylist and she also sells styling creams. She has a big fridge that she uses to sell cold drinks and water. She has been in this business for the past five years. She is a LAPO client.  Ruth needs the loan amount of 50,000 NGN ($375 US) to purchase more hair extensions and styling cream to sell. She says, "thank you to all that made this loan possible."

loans.use: To purchase hair extensions and styling creams to sell.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort sells bags of charcoal and crates of eggs. She makes good profits from this business and this makes her happy. She has been in this business for a long time. Comfort needs the loan amount of 140,000 NGN ($1,000 US) to purchase more bags of charcoal and crates of eggs to sell. Comfort is 50 years old and married with four children. She lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. She says, "thank you to all that made this loan possible."

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal and crates of eggs to sell.

loans.name: Asafa

texts.en: Asafa A. sells dry gin (ogogoro) in her neighborhood. She lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. She has lots of customers that are patronizing her. She hopes to meet the demands of her customers. A. needs the loan amount of 50,000 NGN ($375 US) to purchase more local gin to sell. A. is 40 years old and married with four children. She says, "thank you to all that made this loan possible."

loans.use: To purchase more dry gin (ogogoro) to sell.

loans.name: Oluwaloju

texts.en: Oluwaloju sells snacks, drinks and bottled water. The demands for her goods are high. She has been in this business since 2004. Oluwaloju is 40 years old and married with four children. She needs the loan amount of 140,000 NGN ($1,000 US) to purchase more snacks, drinks and water to sell. She says, "thank you to all that made this loan possible."

loans.use: To purchase more snacks, drinks and water to sell.

loans.name: Norbibi

texts.en:
A good education is the most important inheritance Norbibi and her husband can give to their two dear children. Norbibi and her husband are very responsible parents, and they work very hard in agriculture and farming so that they can give their children the opportunity to finish school – an opportunity they never had due to poor finances. Norbibi has been working in agriculture since getting married. She and her husband buy and sell cattle in order to cover the family’s most urgent needs. Even so, Norbibi now finds herself with more expenses than income, and she would like a loan in order to increase their production. Norbibi and her family are waiting for your quick response.

The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. loans.use: Purchase livestock

loans.name: Ahmadchon

texts.ru: Xошимов Ахмадчон парень в возрасте 30 лет , женат имеет 1 ребёнка.Его бизнес это производство домашних национальных лепёшек.Он арендует комнату в доме своего друга.В его цеху 8 работников.Сам Ахмадчон печёт хлеб в тандыре.Для закупа оптом муки ему недостаточно денежных средств. Для этого он обратился в Микроинвест.Если купить муку за наличные , то Ахмадчон говорит что разница в цене большая , чем за безналичку.Увидев деятельность Ахмадчона явно видно что производство в разгаре,и ему необходимо помочь.Сам Ахмадчон благодарен всем инвесторам.
texts.en:
Ahmadchon H. is 30 years old. He is married and has one child. His business is baking home-made national flat bread. He leases a room at his friend’s house and employs 8 workers. Ahmadchon does not have enough money to purchase flour wholesale, however it makes little business sense to purchase flour at its retail cost; thus, he reached out to MicroInvest for a loan. Ahmadchon’s business is booming, and he is grateful to all of his investors.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Flour purchase

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth sells fruit juice, water and drinks. She also sells rechargeable phone cards. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of 140,000 NGN ($1,000 US) to purchase more fruit juice and drinks to sell. Elizabeth sells daily from 8am to 6pm. She says, "Thank you to all that made this loan possible."

loans.use: To purchase more fruit juice and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Shola Amudat

texts.en: Shola is a hardworking woman. She sells palm and groundnut oil. She also sells eggs. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of 100,000 NGN ($725 US) to purchase more palm and groundnut oil to sell. She hopes to meet the demands of her customers in this festive season. She is 42 years old and married with five children. She says, "Thank you to all that made this loan possible."

loans.use: To purchase more palm and vegetable oil to sell.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha O. is a 36-year-old woman living in the Stella B area of the Rongo District in Kenya. She has been married since 1988 to a driver who works with the local Superfoam Mattress Company. Together, Martha and her husband have 7 children, all of whom are currently enrolled in school. 

Martha has one business selling fresh milk and a second business selling new clothes. Martha buys the fresh milk in bulk from the locally owned Oyami farm and she sells the milk to the community.  For her second business, Martha purchases mainly children’s clothing from the towns of Migori and Kisii, and sells the items in the nearest market. 

Martha started her milk business in 2004, using her own savings as start-up capital. The new clothes enterprise was started with a boost from her husband and from a K-MET loan. 

With the benefits from her previous K-MET loan and her two businesses, Martha makes enough profit to pay the school fees for her seven children, meet her household expenses, and pay for any necessary medical expenses. 

Martha is requesting a loan of KSH 15,000 ($200 USD ) to purchase more clothing for her clothing business. She would like to increase her stock so she has more items for the new year.

loans.use: To purchase clothing items

loans.name: Latif

texts.en:
Latif S. is a 43-year-old married man who lives with his daughter and owns a small farm. He lives and works in the small village of Penjikent, Tajikistan. Latif has a business raising and selling sheep. He has 5 years of experience in this field. 

Because sheep raising and selling is a profitable business, Latif has become a very successful businessman in a very short period of time. He works very hard and spends all his time with the sheep; cleaning, feeding and pasturing them. 

Now, Latif wants to expand his business and buy more sheep, so he has applied for a loan of 2000 Somoni ($600 USD). He promises to repay the loan within 12 months and thanks all lenders for their support. With your help, Latif can get ahead.

loans.use: To buy sheep

loans.name: Muyinot

texts.en: Muyinot sells foodstuffs like rice, beans, plantains, etc. She has been in this business since 2002. The demands for her foodstuffs are high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She needs the loan amount of 70,000 NGN ($500 US) to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. Muyinot is 33 years old and married with a child. She says, "Thank you to all that made this loan possible."

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Tuhfa

texts.ru:
Рахматова Тухфа женщина в возрасте 44 лет имеет троих сыновей.Тухфа занимается продажей продуктов питания по районам Гончи и Масчох.Получив займ она хочет увеличить свой ассортимент товара.Ездиет она
два раза в неделю.У неё свои постоянные клиенты,которые ждут её.Тухфа узнав от подруг,что можно получить кредит для расширения бизнеса обратилась к нам.
texts.en:
Tuhfa R. is 44 years and has three sons. She sells groceries in the Ghonchi and Mastchoh districts. She would like to use this loan to increase the assortment of her products. She delivers her orders twice a week and has many loyal clients. Tuhfa found out about this loan program from her friends and decided to obtain this loan to help grow her business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase products assortment

loans.name: Bahodur

texts.en:
Bahodur M. is 32 years old. He is married with two children. Four years ago, Bahodur started to use his mechanical skills to do work for his neighbors and acquaintances. He learned this skill at another shop and practiced until he had the opportunity to start his own business. 

With his faith and enthusiasm, his auto mechanic business started to grow little by little. Villagers who use machines for their business always come to him to have their machines repaired. Now, Bahodur is finding that the tools that he has are not enough to work at his job with full speed. For this reason, he is seeking a loan of $600 USD that will be paid back over the course of 12 months. This loan will be used to buy tools and materials used to repair autos. With your help, Bahodur will be able to provide for his children's education and the well-being of his family.

loans.use: To purchase tools and materials used to repair cars

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria sells drinks and bottled water. She also bakes snacks to sell. She has been in this business since 2000. Victoria is a 43 years old and she is a widow with three children. She takes care of her children alone and she hopes to give them quality education.  She needs the loan amount of 140,000 NGN ($1,000 US) to purchase more crates of drinks and bottled water to sell. She says, "Thank you to all that made this loan possible."

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks and bottled water to sell.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine O., 33, lives in the village of Achuth in the Rongo District of Kenya. Christine is married to an accountant at the Kenyatta National Hospital. They have 3 children, 2 of whom are currently attending school. 
 
Christine runs a posho mill (a machine that grinds maize into flour) in Achuth, which she started in 2001. On a daily basis, Christine raises between 300-400 KSH. There is stiff competition in the area, as there are other posho mills around. 
 
In 2003, Christine started a second small business selling household items to the local community. She buys her inventory in bulk from Nairobi, where it is less expensive. 

With her two businesses, Christine is able to support her family by paying school fees and taking care of domestic expenses. Christine is rigorous in saving money so that she may soon purchase a parcel of land on which to start a poultry project.  

She is applying for a loan of KSH 22,500 ($USD 300) in order to have enough start-up capital for her dream of a poultry business. With the loan money, Christine will purchase at least 50 broiler chicks to raise and later sell.

loans.use: To purchase chickens

loans.name: Karomatullo

texts.en:
Karomatullo is a young and energetic guy who wants to improve his family's living conditions. He is 21 years old and lives in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. He has a retail shop where sells spare parts for foreign cars. He has been involved in this business for more than 8 years, helping his father before he opened his shop. He provides spare parts for cars and provides his family with food and other necessities.

There is a great demand for Karomatullo's spare parts, so he wants to buy more goods to meet his clients' demands. He wants to take out an individual loan of $600 US dollars to buy more spare parts and enlarge his shop's inventory.  He promises to repay this loan within 12 months. Karomatullo is happy about this loan and would like to thank everyone for the trust and support.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy spare car parts to sell

loans.name: Olawuni

texts.en: Olawuni is 35 years old and married with two children. She is a LAPO client. She sells jewelry and kitchen utensils. She is requesting for the loan amount of 140,000 NGN ($1,000 US) to start selling kerosene. She hopes to combine the two businesses together to help her make more profits to assist her husband in taking care of the children. She says, "Thank you to all that made this loan possible."

loans.use: To purchase kerosene to sell.

loans.name: Edem

texts.en: Edem is 39 years old and married with two children. Edem sells drinks in wholesale and retail to her customers. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. The demands for her drinks are high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She needs the loan amount of 140,000 NGN ($1,000 US) to purchase more drinks to sell. She says, "Thank you to Kiva lenders for their financial support."

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

loans.name: Erkin

texts.en:
Erkin G. offers transportation services in Istaravshan, Tajikistan, his home town. He started his own business 15 years ago after working as a public van driver. His enterprise has been an effective source of income for his family of seven. Erkin works 16 hours a day to provide a decent living for his family. Today, he is planning to replace the fuel supply system with a Kapron gas-cylinder because it's cheaper than using petrol. He requests 2000 Somoni ($600 US Dollars) for the term of 12 months. He thanks everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner. The well-being of this family is on your hands.   


Brief History of Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.   Today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet Republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of the kapron gas-cylinder for the fuel supply system.

loans.name: Olufunke

texts.en: Olufunke is 47 years old and she is a widow with three children. She hopes to pull her family out of poverty. Olufunke sells frozen foods like turkey, chicken, fish, etc. She also sells drinks. She needs the loan amount of 140,000 NGN ($1,000 US) to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She says, "Thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support."

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en: Jessica sells foodstuffs like rice, beans, yams, and plantains. She is a LAPO client. Jessica is 51 years old and married with four children. She needs the loan amount of 140,000 NGN ($1,000 US) to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says, "Thank you to all KIVA lenders and LAPO Microfinance for their financial support."

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Pavlo

texts.en:
Pavlo C. uses his car as a taxi and is his main source of income. His profit is about 1,300 UAH per month. Pavlo has been in this business for 5 years and has been successful. A high unemployment rate in his city required him to be creative with ways to make a living. He is married and has two daughters.  
Pavlo recently got a newer car, and though it's not expensive, it requires frequent maintenance. Pavlo would like a loan of 3,000 UAH ($375) to use for car maintenance. He plans to pay the loan back in 6 months.

loans.use: car maintenance

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! 

Hilda K. from Dar es Salaam runs a business selling spare car parts and has been in the business since 2004. In Tanzania, cars are definitely driven to the full extreme because of ridiculously bumpy dirt roads (especially after the rain has eroded most of the road away), constant swerving and dodging of cars, pedestrians, and animals. Road conditions and driving habits wear the breaks, shocks and steering; requiring fixing and up keep. Many of the cars arriving in Tanzania are already used and often on there last legs. However, cars are expensive and people fix them until they no longer can. Thus, Hilda’s business is essential in Tanzania.

She works 16 hours a day and is assisted by her husband, Paul. She is 32 years old and married with 2 children, who are 5 and 13 years old. Hilda currently earns about $100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $225 in order to increase her inventory. Hilda thanks you for your support!



ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and lease back microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it is allows clients to use equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania!

Rehema I. from Dar es Salaam has been running a cloth and clothing business since 1994. She sells a variety of items including vitambaa (thick cloth with bold and colorful patterns used to make Tanzanian traditional clothing), viatu (shoes), mikoba (bags), madira (plus size clothing for women), and nguoza watoto (children’s clothing).

She works at the business for 5-8 hours a day. Rehema currently earns about $100 USD a month from her business. She is is 37 years old, single with 2 children, who are 11 and 15 years old.  She is requesting a loan of $375 USD to expand her business by increasing her inventory. Rehema thanks you for your support!


ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by increasing her inventory

loans.name: Agness

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 42-year-old Agness B. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with one dependent who is staying with her because the girl is attending school nearby. Agness has been running a drink stall since last year. It is said that Coca Cola is one of the most recognized symbols in the world, and it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of shop selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness. The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing; a very cheap marketing tool! All of which explains why selling drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola, Ltd. in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

Agness works at the business 13-16 hours per day and is assisted by two employees. Agness currently earns about 200 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 775 USD in order to increase her inventory. Agness thanks you for your support! ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Swiga

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Swiga M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children, who are 7 and 11 years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent who is attending school nearby.

Swiga has been running a stationery store since February 2008. Stationery sales is a business in which micro-entrepreneurs demonstrate their business savvy, with most sellers placing their shops, stalls, or tables strategically close to post offices, banks, schools and universities. Shops usually sell a variety of items from pens to books to candy (especially if the shop is near a school). Swiga works at the shop for 5-8 hours per day, six days per week. She currently earns about 20 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 250 USD in order to expand her business by increasing her inventory. Swiga thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 48-year-old Judith K. from Dar es Salaam. She is widowed with three children between the ages of 14 and 24. Judith has been running a general store since 2005, a neighborhood shop in the city where she sells common household and grocery items. She works at the business for 13-16 hours per day, six days per week. Judith currently earns about 20 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 375 USD in order to purchase additional inventory in bulk. Judith thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory in bulk

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 38-year-old Happiness M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children ages two and seven years old. Happiness has been running a pharmacy since 2001. A pharmacy in Tanzania is traditionally a small store that has many glass shelves in which a variety of medicines are displayed, from antibiotic soap to malaria medicine. She works at the business for 13-16 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. She is requesting a loan of 750 USD in order to increase her inventory. Happiness thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Marisiano

texts.en:
Marisiano K. is 32 years old and lives in Gari Village in the Rongo District of Kenya. She runs a food kiosk in the town of Migori, a business she initiated in 2008. Before starting the food kiosk, Marisiano had a vegetable stall for many years.

Currently, Marisiano sells tea, mandazi (fried dough eaten for breakfast), chapatti (a flat bread made with wheat flour similar to a tortilla in shape and size), ugali (a staple carbohydrate made of flour and water), and beef stew, among other items.

The best days for the business are market days, Mondays and Fridays, when people are passing by on their way to and from the local market. On average, Marisiano is able to make a profit of KSH 100 (approximately USD 1.33) a day. She says that she is able to make enough money to pay the household expenses of her family. Marisiano is married to a computer technician and together they have 4 children, all of whom are in school.

Marisiano is applying for a loan of KSH 11,250 (USD 150) in order to purchase food so that she may add more selections to her menu. She would like to be able to cook some dishes that are frequently requested by customers that she is currently unable to make due to lack of ingredients.

loans.use: To purchase food items for preparing dishes to sell

loans.name: Valeriy

texts.en:
Valeriy has a second marriage and a four-month-old son. Valeriy owns a retail business and sells clothes and shoes at a market in Simferopol. His monthly gross income is 10,000 UAH; his profit is about 3,000 UAH.

Valeriy has been in this business for 13 years already. He is an experienced salesperson and has a stable position at the market. He works by himself and knows how to organize this business well. His business goal is to grow bigger. On the other hand, Valeriy has got another goal in his life. He wants to legalize his marriage so that his son can be registered with the father's last name. Valeriy has learned that family is the real value in life, and wants to put family first.

Valeriy would like to receive a loan of 3,000 UAH to increase the assortment of his goods. Having more profit would help him to take better care of his wife and baby son.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of his inventory

loans.name: Damilola

texts.en: Damilola is 28 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a commercial taxi driver. She sells underwear. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of  40,000 NGN to purchase more underwear to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more underwear to sell

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin sells kerosene and has been in this business for a long time. The demand for her kerosene is high. She is a LAPO client. Toyin needs the loan amount of 140, 000 NGN to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Domenica

texts.en:
Domenica is a member of the Señor de Luren Village Bank. She is 34 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their 12-year-old son. Domenica buys firewood from producers who deliver it to her home, then she re-sells the wood from her home. She is also a member of a women’s group that knits sweaters, puppets, and cushions for export.

Domenica needs a loan of 750 soles, which she will use to buy different colors of wool to knit with. Domenica’s dreams are to build her own home and to have her own store.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

Domenica es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Luren. Domenica es conviviente, tiene 34 años y 1 hijo de 12 años, Domenica vende leña en su casa, que compra de los productores que le llevan a su casa. Además Domenica integra una asociación de mujeres que hacen tejidos de chompas, títeres, cojines, productos que envían al extranjero.

Domenica necesita un préstamo de 750 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de lana de diferentes colores. Los sueños de Domenica son construir su casa y tener una bodega.

loans.use: Buy different colors of wool for knitting

loans.name: Claudia

texts.en:
Claudia is a member of the Señor D. Luren Village Bank. She is 54 years old and has eight children. Claudia has a store in her home in the San Melchor neighborhood, where she sells dry goods, vegetables, meat and sodas seven days a week. Claudia also owns a car, which her son drives as a taxi. Claudia needs a loan of 900 soles to buy sugar, rice and milk. Claudia dreams of putting the finishing touches on her home.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

Claudia es socia del Banco Comunal Señor D. Luren. Claudia es casada, tiene 54 años y 8 hijos, Claudia tiene una tienda en su casa ubicada en el barrio D. San Melchor en donD. venD. abarrotes, verduras, carnes, gaseosas, actividad que realiza todos los días. Además Claudia tiene un carro con el cual trabaja su hijo haciendo transporte publico. Claudia necesita un préstamo D. 900 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. azúcar, arroz, leche. Claudia sueña con hacer todos los acabados a su casa.

loans.use: Buy sugar, rice and milk

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
Elvira se dedica a la costura de prendas de mujer (vestidos, faldas, blusas y arreglos en general).
Vive en la zona de villa san Antonio bajo de la ciudad de La Paz, en alquiler.
Está separada de su esposo y tiene una hija que está a su cargo.
El crédito será destinado para la compra de materia prima (tela, encaje, hilo, forros y botones)
Es la cuarta vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial la califica como cliente 1 es decir con buen cumplimiento en el pago de su crédito.
Las ganas de trabajar le dan la oportunidad de acceder a este crédito ya que es una persona responsable.
texts.en:
Elvira makes a living sewing clothing for women (dresses, skirts, blouses and general alterations). She lives in the Villa San Antonio zone, down from the city of La Paz. She rents. She is separated from her husband and has a daughter in her care. The loan is for the purchase of raw materials (cloth, lace, thread, lining material and buttons). This is her fourth loan from Impro. Her credit history qualifies her as a #1 customer, meaning that she has complied with the terms of repayment. Her desire to work gives her the opportunity to be able to request this loan, she is a very responsible person.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cloth, thread, lining, buttons for her dressmaking business of women's clothing.

loans.name: Yemisi

texts.en: Yemisi sells frozen foods like turkey, chicken, fish etc. She sells in wholesale and retail to her customers. She needs the loan amount of 50,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She hopes to meet the demands of her customers during and after this festive season. Yemisi is 50 years old and married with five children. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.en:
Felicitas is a member of the Señor de Luren Village Bank. She is 38 years old and married with five children. She travels to different regional markets twice a week to buy grains, cheese and potatoes, which she then takes to Lima to sell. She also buys fruit in Lima and sells it in local markets. Felicitas needs a loan of 1050 soles to buy corn and wheat. Felicitas dreams of opening a store in her home and of buying a motorcycle taxi for her sons to drive.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

Felicitas es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Luren. Felicitas es casada, tiene 38 años y 5 hijos, Felicitas viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región, dos veces por semana de donde compra cereales, queso, papa, que luego de acopiar lo lleva a la ciudad de Lima y de allá trae frutas y lo vende en las ferias. Felicitas necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que fue invertido en la compra de maíz y trigo. Felicitas sueña con tener una tienda en su casa, comprar mototaxi para que trabajen sus hijos.

loans.use: Buy corn and wheat

loans.name: Zonia Hilda

texts.en:
Zonia is a member of the Cielo (“Sky”) Village Bank. Zonia is 41 years old and married with five children. She lives in the Chumbes community of Ocros District. She buys tara (a pod used to treat leather) and cochinilla (a cactus used to make dyes for clothing and cosmetics) in different local markets each week and sells them to intermediaries, who take the products to the city of Lima to resell. Sonia also has a store in her home, where she sells dry goods, fruits and vegetables. Sonia needs a loan of 450 soles to buy tara and cochinilla. Sonia’s dreams are to improve her businesses and provide her children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

Zonia es socia del Banco Comunal Cielo.
