She began with a different line of business, selling refreshments and breakfast to the coppersmiths of the Monte Rosa sugar refinery: she would distribute the food daily and her husband helped by collecting the payments from her clients. She later decided to make money for her family by starting a grocery and she now has the two businesses. Her goal is to keep both businesses generating income for the family to live on. She needs this loan for working capital to buy staples such as grains, chicken, cream and cheese as she has to stock her grocery to offer her clients what they need.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Yamileth Del Carmen

texts.es:
Esta empresaria Señora Yamileth del Carmen M. González, tiene la edad de 25 años, su estado civil es casada, Doña Yamileth tiene 2 hijos su edades son las siguientes su hijo mayor de 8 años cursa el 4 grado de primaria y su otro hijo de 10 años cursa recientemente el 6 grado de primaria, su esposo labora como sub.-oficial de la policía nacional, sus propósitos son de trabajar siempre para llevar siempre el sustento para su familia para sobrellevar la situación sus sueños son de establecer un tienda de ropa en su casa de habitación donde ofrezca una variedad de productos con el fin de suplir cada una de las necesidades de sus clientes sus deseos son  de obtener su propia casa ya que en la que viven actualmente es en la casa de su Mama y  que Dios le proporcione mas vida para seguir ayudando a sus hijos para salir adelante para que estos sean unos profesionales para el día de mañana y no les falte el sustento de diario.


La actividad económica a la que se dedica es venta de ropa por encargo como lo es: shorts, ropa interior, pantalones y camisetas, la ubicación de su negocio es de forma ambulante ya que tiene que ofrecer de casa en casa el producto, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 3 años, ella inicia este negocio con una venta de refrescos y llamadas telefónicos pero este negocio no proporciono mucha ganancia por lo que decide mantenerlo como otra fuente de ingresos ya que por influencias de una amiga quien le dio la idea de ofertar la ropa por encargo ya que este es una negocio con rentabilidad y poco a poco fue invirtiendo en su negocio hasta que logro este fuera su fuente de ingresos, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo por lo que necesita realizar la compra de calzado, perfumes, ropa y otros encargos por lo que agradece a Fundación León 2000 y las organizaciones amigas que colaboran para mejorar el estado económico de las personas que lo necesitan.
texts.en:
The businesswoman Yamileth del Carmen M. González is 25 years old, is married, and has two children. Her older son is 10 years old and recently enrolled in the sixth grade of primary school, and her younger son is 8 years old and in the fourth grade of primary school. Her husband works as a sub-official of the national police. Her goals are to always work to support her family and improve their situation. Her dream is to establish her own clothing store in her home, where she can offer a variety of products and meet the needs of her clients. She hopes to one day own her own home, as her family currently lives in her mother's house. She also hopes that God will grant her a long life so she can continue helping her children to move forward, pursue professional careers in the future, and be able to meet their daily needs. Yamileth works selling clothing such as shorts, underwear, trousers and shirts. She offers the clothing door to door, taking orders for the items, and has owned this business for 3 years. She first started out selling soft drinks and phone cards, but this activity was not very profitable. A friend suggested that she start selling clothing as this is a profitable activity, and little by little she invested money in this business until it became her main source of income. This loan is for working capital as she needs to purchase shoes, perfume, clothes and other orders. She is thankful to Fundación León 2000 and its partner organizations for improving the economic situation of the people who need their support.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Maria Lorena

texts.es:
La Señora Maria Lorena López Martínez tiene la edad de 54 años, su estado civil es viuda, Doña Maria tiene 5 hijos de los cuales su hijo mayor tiene 38 años de edad y trabaja por cuenta propia su otro hijo de 37 años trabaja por cuenta propia y su otra hija de 34 años que cursa el 4 año de la modalidad diurna su otro hijo de 30 años de edad no estudia y su hijo menor de 28 años que no trabaja, sus propósitos son de seguir con su negocio adelante para sacar adelante a su familia ya que es difícil mantener la situación económica en la que ella se encuentra por  lo que tiene que ayudar a su Mama y a su hijos sus deseos son de seguir luchando para darle mejoras a su vivienda por lo que sus deseos son de transformar su casa y darle un lugar adecuado donde vivir a sus hijos sus sueños son de administrar un negocio de tortillas donde posea una ayudante con la elaboración de las tortillas ya que a su edad no puede pasar mucho tiempo de pie.

La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la venta y elaboración de tortillas y venta de frijoles, la ubicación de su negocio es en reparto Austria, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 4 años, ella inicia este negocio por que necesitaba un medio que le generara ingresos para su familia y acude a la elaboración y venta de tortillas y decide comenzar con medio quintal de maíz por lo que logra ver los resultados de sus sacrificios y mas tarde decide establecer otro negocio como es la venta de frijoles ya que los vendía en un determinado tiempo pero debido a que el precio de este producto escaló  decide quitar la venta de fríjol y mas tarde retorna de nuevo a la venta de frijoles por lo cual es el destino del capital de trabajo para la compra de los productos como frijoles, maíz y leña ya que la inversión de su materia prima es importante para ofertarlos a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Maria Lorena L. Martines is 54 years old, and is a widow. Doña Martina has 5 children. Her oldest son, 38, is self-employed. Her other son, of 34, is also self-employed. Her daughter, also 34, is in her fourth year of secondary school modules. Her son of 30, is not in his studies, and her youngest son of 28 doesn’t work. Maria’s intentions are to continue on with her business to support her family, given that it is difficult to maintain her current economic status because she has to support her mother and her children. Her wishes are to continue struggling to better their quality of life by transforming her house and giving her children an adequate place to live. Her dreams are to administrate a tortilla business, where she would be able to have an assistant with the production of tortillas, as her age does not allow her to spend a great deal of time on her feet. The economic activity that Maria participates in is the production and elaboration of tortillas, and the sale of beans. The location of her business is in the annexed region, Austria. She has had her business for 4 years, starting it because she needed a means of generating income to support her family. She started with the sale of tortillas, with the initial amount of 50 kg of corn, with which she saw the results of her sacrifices. Later, she decided to establish another business in the sale of beans, which she sold for a period of time, until the price of beans as a product escalated. Later, she returned to the sale of beans because it generates the appropriate capital to buy necessary supplies like beans, corn, and wood, because investing in raw materials is necessary so that she may offer her products to her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: capital for her business

loans.name: Agueda De Jesus

texts.es:
La Microempresaria de Nombre Águeda de Jesús Pérez P. tiene la edad de 52 años, su estado civil es soltera, Doña Águeda no tiene hijos, sus propósitos son de mantener activo su negocio ya que es una mujer muy luchadora por lo que de alguna forma a logrado superar los obstáculos mas difíciles de su vida para salir adelante sus deseos son de mantener su negocio activo y que sus productos sena de calidad para que los clientes siempre lleguen en busca de sus productos ya que por su cuadra tiene mucha competencia y no quiere perder la costumbre de vender el tiste ya que es uno de los productos que tradicionalmente se venden en algunos en algunos barrios por lo que también no quiere que esta costumbre se pierda sus sueños son de tener una casa nueva para que su Mama y Ella puedan vivir cómodamente con las condiciones adecuadas para su bienestar por lo que a su edad tiene que pensar en su futuro.


Su actividad económica es la venta de nacatamales, tiste pan y gaseosa, la ubicación de su negocio es en su casa de habitación, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 24 años, Doña Águeda inicia este negocio por su Mama quien al principio era la responsable de este negocio y al paso del tiempo debido a la calidad de los nacatamales logra captar la atención de los clientes logrando así que su negocio tenga el éxito que tiene hasta los momentos y mas tarde debido a la edad decide facilitarle  a su hija el negocio haciendo cargo de el su hija Doña Águeda por lo que ya su Mama le enseño la elaboración de sus productos por lo que no afecto el cambio ya que su hija mantuvo los clientes que su Mama tenia cuando empezó a trabajar  y por no acabar con este negocio es necesario el financiamiento que será destinado para la compra de mas productos y para mantener la venta del nacatamal ya que necesita compra las hojas, maíz, pan y las gaseosas por lo que siempre le ha gustado trabajar con Fundación León 2000 y las organizaciones amigas que se muestran deseosas a sacar a gente que realmente quiere salir adelante con su negocio.
texts.en:
Águeda de Jesús Pérez P. is 52 years old, single, and has no children. Her intentions are to maintain her business activity, after having struggled a great deal to overcome on some level, the most difficult obstacles of her life, to continue on living. Her wishes are also to make sure her products are of quality so that her clients continue coming to her in search of her products. Given that her block has a lot of competition and she doesn’t want to lose the habit of selling bread, especially because it is a product that is part of neighborhood tradition. Her dream is to buy a new house so that her mother and she may live comfortably in adequate conditions for their wellbeing, because her age demands that she prepare for the future. Her economic activity is the sale of nacatamales (a Central American Tamal), bread, and soda. The location of her business is in her house. She has had it for 24 years. Doña Águeda started her business for her mother, who was initially responsible for the business. As time passed, the quality of her mother’s tamales captured the attention of many clients, and the business had a great deal of success, and her mother decided to place her daughter in charge of the business. She taught her how to make the tamales so that the change of management wouldn’t affect the business. Since she has maintained her mother’s original clientele, and so that she doesn’t lose her business, the loan will be used to buy more products, like pots, corn, bread, and sodas. She has always enjoyed working with Fundación León 2000 and their sister organizations that desire to help people that truly want to progress with their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more products for her business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ni Ketut Kasiani

texts.id:
Ni Ketut Kasiani dalam keseharian hidupnya ia mampu membantu suami dalam menambah penghasilan keluarga melalui usaha menjual pulsa dan aksesoris telepon genggam yang berada di depan rumahnya .
Dengan tambahan modal dari DINARI yang merupakan pinjaman untuk periode pertama Ni Ketut Kasiani  bisa menambah jumlah jenis barang yang akan dijual kepada pembeli yang bisa meningkatkan hasil penjualan dan dan juga keuntungan bersih dari hasil usahanya.  Ni Ketut Kasiani bermagsud untuk melanjutkan pinjaman periode ke dua dengan jangka waktu 12 bulan dengan pembayaran dilunasi pada akhir periode pinjaman. sehingga dengan tambahan modal tersebut mereka dapat meningkatkan jumlah persediaan barang maupun pulsa yang akan di jual sehingga keuntungan yang diperoleh akan lebih meningkat guna penunjang pendapatan keluarganya.
texts.en:
Ni Ketut Kasiani sells prepaid cellphone credit and cell phone accessories to get extra income, supplementing her husband's low income to support the family.

She got a loan from DINARI once before and with this loan she was able to add the range of merchandises in her store. She was able to increase her revenue and profit out of it.

She is now planning to take the 2nd term loan from DINARI with a tenor of 12 month period. This loan is repayable at the end of the period. She is hoping to be able to further increase her business.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To add merchandise

loans.name: Sor's Group

texts.en:
There are three members who make up this loan group, and they all reside in Pleung Chess Rotest village of Phnom Penh City. Mrs. Sor S. has been selected to be the leader. She is a local cultivator and is 48. She is growing traditional rice that is the main source for her to earn the money to properly support her family. She is married and is currently responsible for six children: three are single and three are married; two of them are students.

To help meet the family's expenses, three of her children are employed, two as construction workers and another one is a garment worker, while her husband is a local construction worker. In view of the coming harvesting season, Sor S., lacking the money to pay for her harvesting activities, decided to ask for a loan as capital to hire a harvester to harvest her rice crop.

The other two borrowers are:

Mrs. Bo V., 41 years old, who is also a rice farmer. She is applying a loan to pay for her rice crop harvesting.

Mr. Ouch K. earns a living driving a motorcycle taxi and is seeking a loan to hire a harvester to harvest his rice.

loans.use: to hire a harvester to harvest her rice crop

loans.name: Theun

texts.en: Mrs. Theun N. is a villager in Prey Chum village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. She is a 44-year-old widow who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her son is a cabinet maker but neither he nor Mrs. Theun N. has enough money to buy the equipment he needs to make cabinets for his customers. Mrs. Theun N. therefore has decided to ask for a loan to buy cabinetry equipment for her son's business.

loans.use: To purchase cabinetry equipment

loans.name: Sokong

texts.en: Mrs. Sokong N. was born in 1973 and she now lives in Svay Phluos village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. She is a garment factory worker who earns a small salary to support the family. Her husband, Mr. Hun Puy, is a farmer. Although they work hard in different occupations, they still live in an old house in poor condition. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sokong N. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family. Mrs. Sokong N. has three children who are all attending the local school. Her husband is with her in the picture.

loans.use: To build a new house.

loans.name: Aun

texts.en:
Mrs. Aun K. is a villager in Trapaing Lompeak village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for the family. Her husband, Mr. Sak Sim, is a furniture maker who makes cabinets, tables, chairs, and so on. Mrs. Aun K. is 26 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom attends the local school, while the younger is one year old.

Mr. Sak Sim's business is going well and he wants to expand it. So his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy more equipment to make more furniture to sell. They are both shown in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more cabinetry equipment.

loans.name: Som

texts.en: Mr. Som C. was born in 1980 and he is now a bed maker in Trapaing Lompeak village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. His wife, Mrs. Toam Preun, is a housewife. They have three children, one of whom attends the local school while the others are one and three years old.  Since the bedmaking business is going well, Mr. Som C. wants to expand it so he decided to ask for a loan to buy the supplies and equipment needed to expand.

loans.use: To expand a bedmaking business.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mrs. Mom H. is a villager in Tumnop Ang village in Kampong Speu province, Cambodia.  She is a 33-year-old widow with two children, one of whom attends the local school while the younger is only five years old.  Mrs. Mom H. works as a rice middleman, buying rice and keeping it in inventory for later re-sale at a better price. Since this business is going well, she decided to ask for a loan to expand it.

loans.use: To expand a rice-selling business.

loans.name: Sambor

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambor S. was born in 1967 and she now lives in Prey Sbov village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Reach Sangsa, makes fireworks in their village. They have four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory. The remaining three attend the local school.

Mr. Reach Sangsa's business is going well and he wants to expand it. Mrs. Sambor S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more materials to make fireworks for sale.

loans.use: To expand a fireworks business

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en:
Mr. Pheap S. is a 22-year-old villager in Prey Chum village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. He earns a small living by making beds, while his wife, Mrs. Mao Meun, works a plot of land to cultivate rice.  They have one young child. 

Although Mr. Pheap S. and his wife have different incomes, they still cannot support the family well. To improve their standard of living, Mr. Pheap S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a calf that he hopes will increase his income after he sells it as a mature cow.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Chandy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chandy S. is a farmer in Prey Chum village in Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. She is 23 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local school while the younger one is only five years old.  Her husband, Mr. Mao Phon, is a palm juice collector who gathers juice to process into palm sugar and wine. Although they have different businesses, they still cannot support their family well. 

They now are building a house, but unfortunately they have insufficient money to build the staircase. In order to achieve their purpose, Mrs. Chandy S. decided to ask for a loan to build the staircase.

loans.use: To build the staircase for a new house.

loans.name: Kunthea

texts.en:
Mrs. Kunthea L. is a 39-year-old rice and vegetable farmer who lives in Snam Pok village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. Her husband, Mr. Lan Yong, is a rice middleman who buys rice for later resale at a better price. They have three children who are all attending the local school.

Since Mr. Lan Yong's business is going well, he wants to expand it. Mrs. Kunthea L. has decided therefore to ask for a loan to buy more rice inventory.

loans.use: To more rice inventory.

loans.name: Khom

texts.en: Mrs. Khom S. is a 46-year-old villager in Snam Pok village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who earns a small rice revenue to support the family. Her husband, Mr. Cheing Khon, collects palm juice to process into palm sugar or wine. He now faces a problem because he does not have enough money to buy the bamboo that he ties to the palm trees in order to climb them and gather their juice. Thus, Mrs. Khom S. decided to ask for a loan to buy the bamboo that her husband needs. Mrs. Khom S. is the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory and another helps the parents. The remaining two children attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy bamboo for scaffolding.

loans.name: Mrs. Non Sou Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank group consists of thirteen people in Prey Sbov village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. Mrs. Non S., a 56-year-old widow with four children,was selected by the members to be village bank president. She is a rice farmer who owns a plot of land. Two of her four children have jobs--one is a cook and the other works for an NGO--and the remaining two work on her farm. Mrs. Non S. now faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to buy rice seed or fertilizer.  She will use her portion of the loan to purchase them, enabling her to cultivate her field.   All the members are shown in the picture, but one is blocked at the back.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Ten members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Koeun

texts.en: Mrs. Koeun K. is a villager in Kralanh village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. She is a garment factory worker who earns a small salary to support her family. Since her workplace is far from home, she usually spends a lot of money on transportation. Therefore,she decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband to take her to work. Her husband, Mr. Lon Loeun, is a farmer. Mrs. Koeun K. is 28 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local school while the younger is one year old.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Serey

texts.en:
Mrs. Serey C. is a farmer in Sarika Keo village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. In addition to her farm, she owns a small grocery store. Her husband, Mr. Phoeung Heang, makes beds for sale. His business is going well and he wants to expand it, so Mrs. Serey C. asked for a loan to purchase the necessary materials and equipment.

Mrs. Serey C. is 27 years old and the mother of three young children, one of whom is enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase bed-making materials and equipment.

loans.name: Kren

texts.en: Mrs. Kren T. was born in 1961 and she now lives in Trapaing Ktom village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Moeurn Chey, is a taxi driver. In this business, he now faces a problem because his car’s engine needs to be changed; unfortunately, he does not have enough money to buy an engine for his car. Thus, Mrs. Kren T. decided to ask for a loan to buy it for her husband. Mrs. Kren T. has three children who are all attending the local school.

loans.use: To purchase an engine for a taxi.

loans.name: Bora

texts.en: Mrs. Bora Puth is a villager in Ang Sandann village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who cultivates rice on a plot of land. Her husband, Mr. Yang Sok, is a carpenter who makes doors, windows, and so on. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it. Mrs. Bora Puth decided to ask for a loan to buy more materials and equipment for her husband's business. Mrs. Bora Puth is 23 years old and the mother of two young children.

loans.use: To buy carpentry materials and equipment.

loans.name: Phoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Phoeun S. is a farmer in Vath Khdey village, Kampong Speu province, Cambodia. She cultivates both rice and vegetables. She is 55 years old and the mother of two children who are both employed in a garment factory. Because their workplace is far from home, they usually spend a lot of money on transportation. Mrs. Phoeun S. wants to buy a motorbike for her children Thus, she asked for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike and she hopes to reduce the family's expenses with this solution. Her husband, Mr. Keo Deourn, helps his wife on the farm.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Sum L., 29, is single and lives with her mother and her three younger sisters and brothers in Prey Chhor district, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia.

She works with her mother on her paddy growing seasonal rice and vegetables, but the money they make is barely enough to support their household. Meanwhile, her little brother and sister are employed making incense with one of her neighbors, earning US$ 4/day each. Incense-making is a profitable business in her town and it’s simply to work on to generate profit.

Having a very close relationship with her neighbor, Sum L. would like to invest with him in the business by purchasing more items to increase their production. Meeting the financial constraints, Sum L. would like to request a loan from KIVA to put toward her investment.

loans.use: To use for her investment in a neighbor's business

loans.name: Leang

texts.en:
Mrs. Leang T., age 45, works on her rice paddy growing rice in two seasons, the dry season and the rainy season. She started her farming activity when she was 29.

The rainy season rice lasts about six months longer than the dry season rice, taking only three to three and a half months to generate output. With her farming activity, Leang T. cannot make enough to support her household. Her husband and her three employed children are the key people who are responsible for food and other expenses in the family.

Her husband is a policeman making US$ 2/day and her three children are employed by a local garment factory making about US$ 4/day each.

Recently, Mrs. Leang T. decided to ask for a loan from KIVA to purchase a water pump, fertilizer, and insecticide to increase her rice output so that she can sell it for additional profit.

loans.use: to purchase a water pump, fertilizer, and insecticide to increase her output

loans.name: Malaetele

texts.en: Malaetele A., 48, is married with three children.  She has two years of experience in the Taro banana business. She sells to the village people and to the public one day per week. She is a new member, and this is her first loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 100 Tala.  SPBD loans are Malaetele’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband does the farming.

loans.use: Purchase Gromozone and sacks of fertilizer to maintain business growth

loans.name: Lima

texts.en: Lima A., 57, is married with six children.  She has three years of experience in the taro, taamu, banana business. She sells to the village people and to the public two days per week. She is a new member, and she has one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 120 Tala.  SPBD loans are Lima’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband does the farming.

loans.use: Purchase more farming equipment to maintain business improvement

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en: Elisapeta F., 47, is married with four children.  She has two years of experience in the plantation ava business. She sells to the village people and to the public one day per week. She is a new member, and this is her first loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala.  SPBD loans are Elisapeta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband does the farming.

loans.use: To buy more farming equipment and to expand her shop to maintain business growth

loans.name: Suliveta

texts.en:
Suliveta L. is 40 years old, and married with five children. She has 3 years of experience in the plantation and ice cake business. She sells to the village people and to the public primary school two days a week. Her husband does the farming.

Suliveta is a new member who has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala (~$25 USD). SPBD loans are Suliveta’s only access to capital because she has not qualified for a loan with the traditional banks. She would like a loan of $275 to start her ice cake business and farm her plantation.

loans.use: To start over her ice cake business and expand her plantation

loans.name: Masepi

texts.en: Masepi M. is 24 years old and single.  She is just starting out in the donuts\cake business. She sells to the school and to the village people five days a week. She is a new member and has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 120 Tala (~$40 USD). SPBD loans are Masepi’s only access to capital because she doesn't qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan of $275 to start her business.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of flour and cooking oil to start her bakery business

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en:
Tuy S., 37, is married and has two children who are enrolled in school. She owns a business selling a variety of vegetables at an open-air market and can typically make about US$ 5/day in income. She started her business in 1979 when she was liberated from the Khmer Rouge “Pol Pot regime” which is a black period in Cambodian history, killing nearly three million Cambodians.

Her husband can typically make US$ 2.40/day in income from working as a motor-taxi driver transporting passengers to different locations in his community. The motor-taxi business in Cambodia right now is getting better because the price of gasoline keeps going down from day to day. The price is 3000 Riel per liter as compared to the inflationary period when it was about 5800 Riel.

Tuy S. has recently requested a loan to purchase more vegetables to expand her inventory as the Lunar New Year is coming soon, so the inventory expansion is a priority to allow her to meet the needs of about two or three times as many customers as she usually has.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to expand her inventory to meet her growing customer demand

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Avepea

texts.en: Avepea N. is 30 years old and single. She has 6 months of experience in the yam and taro plantation business. She sells to the village people 1 day a week. She is a new member with no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 60 Tala (~$20 USD). SPBD loans are Avepea’s only access to capital because she did not qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Avepea would like a loan of $275 to expand her farming business.

loans.use: To maintain and expand her taro/yam plantation

loans.name: Avei

texts.en: Avei S., 41, is married with 5 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells to the village people 3 days a week. Avei is a new member and has not taken previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 50 Tala (~15USD). SPBD loans are Avei’s only access to capital because she did not qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Avei will use the loan to buy farm equipment for her taro business while her husband does the farming.

loans.use: To purchase equipment to maintain her taro farm

loans.name: Feagiai

texts.en: Feagiai T., 42, is married with four children. She is starting a taro and vegetable farming business. She sells to the village people two days a week. She is a new member and has received no previous loans with SPBD. Feagiai expects her weekly net cash flow to be 40 Tala (~$12 USD). SPBD loans are Feagiai’s only access to capital because she did not qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She would like a loan of $275 to buy fertilizer, spades, and bush knives.

loans.use: To start her vegetable farming business

loans.name: Ruta

texts.en: Ruta Tuaoimaalii, 46, is married with six children.  She has 4 years of experience in the taro and banana farming business. Her husband does the farming. She sells to people in the village two days a week. Ruta is a new SPBD member. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala (~$25USD).  SPBD loans are Ruta’s only access to capital because she was unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She would like a loan of $275 to support her business.

loans.use: To buy farm equipment to improve taro/banana production

loans.name: Masele

texts.en: Masele T., 51, is married with seven children. She has 6 months of experience farming vegetables. Masele and her husband grow cabbages, cucumbers, and tomatoes, which they sell to people in the village three days a week. Masele is a new member of SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 70 Tala (~$25USD). SPBD loans are Masele’s only access to capital because she was unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She would like a loan of $275 to improve her business.

loans.use: Buy equipment to maintain and improve her vegetable farm

loans.name: Pepe

texts.en: Pepe U., 70, is married with eight children. She is starting her own business selling chickens to the people in the village three days a week. Pepe is a new member of SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 50 Tala (~ $15USD). SPBD loans are Pepe’s only access to capital because she was unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan of $275 to establish her business.

loans.use: To start her business selling chickens

loans.name: Peresia

texts.en: Peresia M. is 18 years old and married.  She has a pancake business and sells to people in the village five days a week. She is a new member of SPBD. Peresia expects a weekly net cash flow of 50 Tala (~$15USD). SPBD loans are Peresia’s only access to capital because she was unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to establish her business.

loans.use: To establish her bakery business

loans.name: Lagi

texts.en: Lagi F. is 34 years old and single.  She has 1 year of experience in the cigarette business. She sells to the village people five days a week. She is a new member of SPBD.  Lagi expects her weekly net cash flow to be 120 Tala (~$40USD).  SPBD loans are Lagi’s only access to capital because she was unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan of $275 to expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase more goods to maintain and improve her business

loans.name: Oreni

texts.en: Oreni A. is 28 years old, and married with three children. She makes pancakes and sells them to people in the village five days a week. She is a new member of SPBD. Oreni expects her weekly net cash flow to be 60 Tala (~$20USD). SPBD loans are Oreni’s only access to capital because she was unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan of $275 to establish her business.

loans.use: To establish her bakery business

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en:
Mrs. Tuy S., 44, is married and has six children. Three of them are enrolled in school and three work as laborers. 
S. and her husband have a seasonal fruit reselling business. She has a lot of business during mango season because mangoes are very popular in Cambodia. S. and her husband travel a lot to purchase large quantities of mangoes to sell to other resellers, wholesale and retail. This month, bananas are in season, and S. and her husband are traveling to the banana plantations to purchase as many mangoes as possible.
S. and her husband make around $15.60 per day selling fruit. However, she has many monthly expenditures of around $65 on food, $15 on utilities, $10 on transportation, $15 on her children’s tuition, and other assorted expenses.
S. is requesting a loan to be able to purchase more fruit so she will be able to sell more of it and make a larger overall profit.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits to increase her inventory

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loans.name: Dik

texts.en:
Dik N., age 43, is married with two children, ages 15 and 17. She sells fish at Phsar Pa Av market, Kampong Cham province. Dik N. purchases fish from the brokers who bought from fisherman and delivers some to the vendors at a market and keeps some for her own stand. She can typically make about $2.50 a day of net income.

Her husband works growing yams, earning around $2 a day. The revenue she and her husband make has to cover the family’s expenses, such as $40 per month on food and $15 per month on her children's tuition. Dik N. and her husband request a loan from KIVA to buy insecticide for their yam crops and to buy more seeds to increase the output.

loans.use: To buy insecticide and seeds to increase their crops.

loans.name: Tusiata

texts.en: Tusiata I., 25, is married with three children. She has 5 years of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells to people in the village 1 day a week. She is a new member of SPBD. Tusiata expects her weekly net cash flow to be 50 Tala (~$15USD). SPBD loans are Tusiata’s only access to capital because she was unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan of $275 to expand her taro farming business.

loans.use: To expand her taro plantation

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en: Loreta L., 35, is married with 5 children.  She is starting her own business fishing and selling her catch to the people in the village 3 days a week. She is a new member of SPBD. Loreta expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala (~$25USD). SPBD loans are Loreta’s only access to capital because she was unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to establish her fishing business.

loans.use: To buy fishing equipment like goggles, nets, a new canoe, and a torch

loans.name: Faitau

texts.en: Faitau M., 34, is married with 6 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells to the village people and public 1 day per week. Faitau is requesting a loan of $275 to expand her plantation.  SPBD loans are Faitau’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To expand her taro plantation

loans.name: Mang

texts.en: Mrs. Mang S. S. P., age 20, is married and lives with her husband and her young son in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She has began a beauty salon and hair dressing shop in 2007, and it has been extremely successful.  Each day she typically makes a profit of about $2.50, but during her busy season, the wedding months of November and December, her profit increases. Before the wedding begins, many guests that are invited will come to her shop to make up their face, hair, and polishing their skin. Lately, S. P. has applied for a loan from KIVA to purchase more hairdressing tools and other materials for her shop to meet her clients’ needs.

loans.use: To buy more make up products to satisfy her client needs.

loans.name: Fialupe

texts.en: Fialupe P. is 29 years old, and married with 6 children.  She has one years of experience in the taro growing business. Besides growing taro, she sells to the people in her village and to the public one day every week. Fialupe is a member of SPBD and she has made a previous loan with this microbank.  With this, her second loan, she expects her weekly net cash flow to be around 50 Tala.  SPBD loans are Fialupe’s only access to business capital as she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase farming equipment and expand her taro planting

loans.name: Vaosa

texts.en: Vaosa T., 23, is married with one child.  She has 3 years of experience in the chicken business. She sells to the village people and public 2 days per week. She is a new member of SPBD, and has taken one previous loan with them.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 40 Samoan Tala ($275 US). SPBD loans are Vaosa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She has no other useful common skills.

loans.use: To purchase fencing, nails, a hammer and timber to expand her poultry farm.

loans.name: Malia Lulia

texts.en: Malia T., 77, is widowed with 12 children. She has 3 years of experience in the taro, taamu, yam, and banana selling business. She sells to the village people and public 2 days per week. She is a new member of SPBD, and has taken just one loan previously with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 60 Samoan Tala (20 USD).  SPBD loans are Malia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase Gromozone, sacks of fertilizers and a fence to expand her plantation.

loans.name: Puleono

texts.en: Puleono E., 29, is married with 3 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the fish and seafood business. She sells to the village people and public 3 days per week. She is a new member, and has taken just one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 70 Samoan Tala ($24 US).  SPBD loans are Puleono’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband is a fisherman who is helping her with the business.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and equipments to replace the old ones to maintain her fishing business.

loans.name: Vaialii

texts.en: Vaialii L., 52, is married with 6 children. She has 3 years of experience in the fish and seafood business. She sells to the village people and public 5 days per week. She is a new member of SPBD and has taken one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 180 Tala ($60 US).  SPBD loans are Vaialii’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband is a fisherman.

loans.use: To purchase new fishing equipment to replace the old.

loans.name: Palanitina

texts.en: Palanitina S., 40, is married with 6 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the pork cake business. She sells to the Village people and  Primary school 5 days per week. She is a new member with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~ USD).  SPBD loans are Palanitina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of flour, gallons of cooking oil and a large pot and a frying pan to expand and maintain the good of her pork cake business

loans.name: Farani

texts.en: Farani S., 34, is single with 0 children.  She has 2 year(s) of experience in the taro, taamu, yam (platation) business. She sells her products to the people in her village as well as to the general public 1 day per week.. She is a new SPBD member with this being her first loan.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 60 Tala (~ 20 USD).  SPBD loans are Farani’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase farming equipments to expand the plantation

loans.name: Luaiva

texts.en: Luaiva T., 31, is divorced with 2 children.  She has no experience in the ice cake business. She sells to the village people and primary school 7 days per week. She is a new member requesting her first loan. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 100 Tala.  SPBD loans are Luaiva’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of sugar, Koolaid, foam cups and a refrigerator to start up her ice cake business

loans.name: Saomalie

texts.en: Saomalie F., 33, is married with 2 children.  She has 4 years of experience in the sales business. She sells to the village people and public 7 days per week. She is a new member and this is her first loan. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala.  SPBD loans are Saomalie’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase more goods for her shop and a freezer  to maintain business improvement

loans.name: Lesina

texts.en: Lesina I., 54, is married with 6 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the taro, taamu (giant taro: a starchy, staple root crop), and banana business. She sells to the village people and public 3 days per week. She is a new member and this is her first loan request. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 100 Tala.  SPBD loans are Lesina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase fencing to expand her plantation

loans.name: Luatasi

texts.en: Luatasi K., 32, is married with 3 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the taro, banana, and vegetable business. She sells to the village people and public 5 days per week. She is a new member and this is her first loan request. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 90 Tala.  SPBD loans are Luatasi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase fencing to expand her plantation and sacks of fertilizer

loans.name: Soli

texts.en: Soli L., 59, is married with six children.  She doesn't have much experience in the ice cake and salad business. She sells to the village people and public 7 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD, so this will be her first loan.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 60 Tala.  SPBD loans are Soli’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase a refrigerator to cool the ice-cake

loans.name: Barbara

texts.en: Barbara M., 32, is married with 4 children. She has 1 year of experience in the Sewing business. She sells to the Village people and Public 6 days per week. She is a new member to kiva. She has no previous loan(s) with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 70 Tala (24 USD). SPBD loans are Barbara’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase new sewing machine to improve her sewing business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married with one child; she lives in Ndamukong, Bamenda, Cameroon. She had already successfully taken out and repaid loans to cultivate crops and rear livestock.  She is now asking for a loan to buy a motorbike. The motorbike will be used as a taxi, driven by her son who will pay her an amount of his daily earnings. Bikes are one of the most efficient forms of transport in and around Bamenda. Bikes are often able to move through damaged roads more efficiently than cars. She will continue working hard with the support of her son to improve her family's standard of living. Elizabeth also plans to take care of her family, ensure that they eat well and buy their medication. She is confident that she will be able to repay this loan because of the low interest rate and the lengthy repayment period.  
 
This is Elizabeth’s fifth loan; she has been a Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) member since 2003. The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and the alleviation of poverty through a multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, and family values.  Clients are also required to put a small amount of their earnings into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of Motorbike, fuel and Documents

loans.name: Nuuao

texts.en: Nuuao M. is a 66 year old women who is married and cares for 9 children. She sells her products to the village people and public 2 days a week. She has received one loan in the past from SPBD. SPBD loans are Nuuao’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase expand the plantation

loans.name: Uefa

texts.en: Uefa M. is a farmer that sells her harvest to numerous village people.  Due to her lack of land she has a limited amount of produce items that she can sell.  Uefa plans to use the loan to expand her faming area.

loans.use: Purchase more land

loans.name: Sitina

texts.en: Sitina P., 37, is married with 1 child. She sells to the Village people one day per week. SPBD loans are Sitina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She thanks you in advance for the loan.

loans.use: Purchase to start her plantation

loans.name: Iliganoa

texts.en: Iliganoa S., 54, is married with 5 children.  She has many years of experience in the Elei materials business. Four days a week, she sells to the public as well as the small shops in her village. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 700 Tala (~291 USD).  SPBD loans are Iliganoa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. All will be used to expand and improve her business. Both her and her husband are selfemployed in running their business.

loans.use: Purchase printing boards, fabric paints, poplin and mull materials, plain t/shirts, paint brush, glitters, and designed stencils

loans.name: Luka

texts.en:
Luka A., 71, is married with 6 children. She has many years of experience in the sewing business. She sells to her regular clients, family and friends 4 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 700 Tala (~291 USD).

SPBD loans are Luka’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to purchase an over-lock machine, cotton material, and sewing equipment such as scissors, thread, and needles to further improve her business.

loans.use: Purchase an over-lock machine, poplin and linen material, thread, needles and zippers

loans.name: Soolefai

texts.en:
Soolefai H., 24, is single with no children. She has several years' experience in the Elei (handmade traditional printed cloth) business. She sells to young people and the general public 3 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.

Soolefai expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD). SPBD loans are Soolefai’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy fabric paints, brushes, printing boards and fabrics to run the business.

loans.use: Purchase rollers, fabric paint, brushes, printing boards, and fabrics

loans.name: Che Beltha

texts.en:
Born in 1957, Beltha is married to Che Thomas and they have one child; she lives in Ntambesi, within the town of Bamenda, Cameroon. She plans to invest this loan in a motorbike. In the past she has taken out loans to sell vegetables, and do crops and pig farming. The motorbike will be used as a taxi in the area. She has already found a driver (her son) for her bike who will pay her at the end of each day.

This is Beltha’s fifth loan; she has been a GHAPE member since 2003. Bikes are one of the most efficient forms of transport in and around Bamenda. As many of the roads are in shambles, bikes are often able to move through these areas quicker and without suffering as much damage as cars. Beltha will continue her profitable firewood business for extra income.

Recently Beltha was very upset when her husband sold their only piece of land. And he also married another lady and stopped paying school fees for their son. Beltha is ready to build her life back with loans from GHAPE and collaboration from her son.

With the profit from this loan, Beltha plans to repair her family house. She also plans to take care of her family, pay school fees, ensure that they eat well, and buy their medication. She knows she will be able to repay this loan because of the low interest rate and the lengthy repayment period.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of a motorbike, fuel, and paying for documents

loans.name: Ipagala 1 Group

texts.en:
Mwamvita has owned a small food and flower store in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for the last three years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 90 USD. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food materials for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and improve her home. She is 28 years old, married, and has two children ages four and eight. She also cares for one additional dependent.

She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members: Siwema, Zainabu, Jane and Doroth. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her market

loans.name: Ipagala 1 Group

texts.en:
Tatu has owned a small charcoal store and been a vegetable seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for ten years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 95 USD. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and vegetables for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, pay school fees and improve her home.

Tatu is 36 years old, married, and has five children between the ages of three and 17. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members: Rebecca, Joina, and Lineth. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Chadulu 1 Group

texts.en:
Eliza is a clothes seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 95 USD. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Eliza is 23 years old, single, and has two children aged two and five. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Rehema, Pendo,and Vumilia. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhoun S. was born in 1950. She and her husband, Heang Touch, 51, are residents of Siem Reap Province. They have five children, three of whom are single; another two are married and live away from their parents' home. Three of their children are employed; their first child is a fish seller, their second child raises pigs, and their third child is a construction worker.

The couple makes a living selling fish in the local Rolosh Market, collecting fish from fishermen and using a motorcycle to transport them to where they retail the fish. They normally earn an income approximately of US$ 10 per day and have been in their business since 2000. Recently, they are facing difficulties with their old motorbike that frequently has problems, thus they would like to ask for a US$ 500 loan to purchase a new motorcycle to replace their existing one.

loans.use: to purchase a new motorcycle to replace their existing one which is often broken

loans.name: Chadulu 1 Group

texts.en:
Moshi is an alcohol vendor in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 80 USD. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can purchase inventory for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Moshi is 35 years old, married, and has six children between the ages of five and 19. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Magreth and Ana. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of liquor

loans.name: Winifred

texts.en:
Born on the 28th December 1968, Winifred is married with five children; she lives in Musang, a quarter in Bamenda, Cameroon. She intends to invest this loan in her motorbike transport business. She plans to purchase a motor bike and fuel and pay for the documents with her loan of 500,000 cfa.

Winifred has been a GHAPE client since September 9th, 2003 and this is her fifth loan. She has seen that there is a high demand in her community for transport and this is her second time in the motorbike business. She plans to contribute to her community by transporting residents to various destination of their choice.

This loan will help her financial situation by providing her with a quick turnover investment and high profits through her motorbike transport business. Moreover, Winifred sells vegetables in the food market in Bamenda to cover daily family expenses when there less work for motorbikes.

With the profits from this loan, Winifred plans to pay for her daughter to enroll in the university and construct her own house. She also will make sure her family eats well and stays healthy. Finally, she hopes to place much of her profit into her personal savings account that GHAPE provided for her. She is happy to be taking out another loan with GHAPE, and she knows her success will be greater with each loan as she receives more business and life skills training from GHAPE.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying a motor bike, fuel, and the documents for the motorbike

loans.name: Chadulu 1 Group

texts.en:
Kuruthum owns a small charcoal store and sells alcohol in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 185 USD. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more materials for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Kuruthum is 29 years old, married, and has two children aged 11 and 9. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Emmi and Eliza. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To expand her business by buying more materials

loans.name: Chadulu G Group

texts.en:
Rehema is a clothes seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 90 USD. Each day she works for nine hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Rehema is 32 years old, married, and has one child who is six years old. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Judith, Elister, and Ruth. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to expand her business

loans.name: Chadulu G Group

texts.en:
Neema owns a small food shop in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 60 USD. Every day she works for 6 hours in her business. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and to save money.

Neema is 40 years old, married, has four children between the ages of four and 18. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Olipa, Tatu, and Frola. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam S. was born in 1957 and is a widow. She currently lives in Siem Reap Province. She has two children, both of whom are employed and earn money to help meet with family's living expenses. 

Since 2004, Sam has run a business selling fish in local Kompong Kdei Market, and is currently earning an average of $2 each day. She uses her own old bicycle for her business activities. Because fish selling is the main way for her to earn money, to make her business transportation easier, S. is applying a loan to purchase a second-hand motorcycle to replace her old bicycle. The motorcycle will be used to transport fish and to bring the family to work.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand motorcycle to replace her old bicycle

loans.name: Polota Kakira Development Association Group

texts.en: Salama M., in her mid 30’s, is the chairperson of Polota Kakira development association in Kakira. She is a hard working business lady with a salon that she has owned since 2000. She has rented the same premises since then. In the salon, she does all sorts of hairstyles like braiding, weaving, retouch, treatments and plus so much more.  She uses mostly  materials and chemicals that she buys from the moving beauty product trucks.This  means that she does not have to spend money on transport. In addition to the salon, Salama also sells cold soft drinks and beers from a fridge in her salon selling to mostly her salon customers, neighbors and passers by. She sells soda, mineral water, juice and beers as another way of increasing her income. In the salon, Salama employs 3 girls who help to attend to the customers. She also has two  more girls who are learning hairstyling from her.  For each to learn, they pay about $120 for the six months course. Salama is grateful for her loans for the four years she has been in this association and this time round, she needs a loan to help her buy more weaves, braids and chemicals for her salon since most of them were used up during the festive season.

loans.use: Weaves, braids, chemicals, and cold drinks to sell in her salon.

loans.name: Chadulu G Group

texts.en:
Yunis is a tailor working in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 70 USD. Each day she works for 6 hours in her business. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more tailoring items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and to save money.

Yunis is 39 years old, married, and has two children aged one and seven; she also cares for two additional dependents. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Digna, Pili, Ana, and Yunis. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To purchase tailoring supplies

loans.name: Hilal

texts.en:
HilA. is a 39-year-old man who lives in Saida, in southern Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. HilA. has been working as a taxi driver, and he has also owned a school bus for four years. 

HilA. requested a loan of $1200 US dollars from A. Majmoua to do some maintenance work on his school bus. This is his second loan cycle and he has always paid on time. 

The loan helped him in a good way. HilA. was able to do some maintenance work on his taxi cab. HilA.'s work is speciA., because of his punctuality and his enjoyment of his work. His clients are students, friends, family members, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he lacked cash. He decided to do this work because he likes it and is especially grateful for its sustainability. In the future, he plans to purchase a bigger bus.

loans.use: Hilal needs the loan to do some maintenance work on his school bus.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is a 32-year-old man who lives in Saida, in southern Lebanon. Simon has been working as a taxi driver for fifteen years. He requested a loan of $1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua to do some maintenance work on his taxi cab. This is the first time that Simon has requested a loan.

Simon is speciA. in his work because his car is still in good condition and is clean. His clients are friends, family members, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, it was difficult for Simon to save money in order for him to purchase his own taxi cab. In the future, he plans to buy a new car.

loans.use: Simon will use the loan to do some maintenance work on his taxi cab.

loans.name: M/mpya E Group

texts.en:
Monica has owned a small charcoal store in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for the last 20 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 250 USD. Every day she works for 12 hours in her business. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Monica is 29 years old, married, and has two children aged three and eight years old; she also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Anna, Fatuma, Halima and Stella. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to increase her current stock

loans.name: Moussa

texts.en:
Moussa is a 21-year-old man who lives in Saida, in southern Lebanon. Moussa has been working as barber since 2002. He also sells men's perfumes, and shaving and cleaning products for men. Moussa has requested a loan of $1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua to purchase gel, bags, necklaces, perfumes and other accessories for men. This is the first time that Moussa has requested a loan.

Moussa is special in his field, because his workplace is clean, his work is good, and he is fast. His clients are his friends, family members and neighbors. When he first started his business, he lacked cash, which made him borrow money. Now, thanks to his work, he has been able to use his business income to repay his loan. 

Moussa decided to be a barber, because he learned it in a academy, and he gained experience in one of his friend’s salons.

loans.use: Moussa will use the loan to purchase gel, bags, necklaces, perfumes and other men's accessories.

loans.name: M/mpya E Group

texts.en:
Witness runs a small charcoal store and sells clothes in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma, which she has done for three years now. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 370 USD. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and clothes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.

Witness is 40 years old, married, and has three children between the ages of 10 and 15. She also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Elizabeth, Mary, and Shukrani. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Lon

texts.en:
Lon C., age 25, raises pigs in a stall next to her house. She also grows vegetables, such as cabbage, morning glory, and cucumbers, and sells them to a market-seller three months after they mature. 

She is married to Chaiy Sithoun, who is 28 years old, and who works with her growing vegetables. The young couple is responsible for a one lovely young child. C. recently sold all her pigs to a slaughterer. She hopes to acquire another pig to raise. 

Therefore, she would like to ask for a loan to buy more piglets to raise. The loan will allow her to increase her revenue and make sure her child receives higher education. The family lives in Siem Reap Province.

loans.use: to buy more piglets to raise

loans.name: M/mpya E Group

texts.en:
Julieth owns a small charcoal store and sells clothes in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma, which she has done for the last five years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 175 USD. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and clothes for her inventory. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.

Julieth is 26 years old, single, and has one child who is seven years old; she also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Sharifa, Teddy, Dotto and Zuhura. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and clothes for her business

loans.name: Chanthou

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthou Y., age 47, is a widow with two children: one son who is married and lives outside the family house, and one daughter, who attends school. She also has three brothers and sisters who live with her. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Chanthou has been selling food and soft drinks for one year, a skill she learned by herself since her husband died. She buys ingredients from Prek Phnao market to cook and sell in her village. She hopes that she will be able to support her children to study as long as possible. She is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike for her daughter to drive to school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her daughter to drive to school.

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambath S., 50, and her husband, Mr. Kinsong Po, 49, married in 1981 and have five children. Two of them are married and live outside the family home; two children are in school and another child stays at home to assist his mother in farming. The family lives along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sambath has been farming for 28 years and her husband has been a mason for 28 years as well. Beside farming, she also sells fruit. She buys it from her villagers for re-sale at Chbar Ampov market in Phnom Penh. Sambath is applying for a loan of US$ 500 to purchase construction materials for her husband; she will use another part of the loan for farming and to buy fruit on contract for re-sale.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials, using part for farming, and to buy fruit for resale.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi Minh Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Minh sinh năm 1955 ( Mã số: 010107050021 ).. Hiện gia đình cô nuôi 10 con lợn thịt và một đàn lợn con. Chị là giáo viên mầm non nhưng vẫn tăng gia sản xuất. Chồng và hai con chị hang ngày đều đi làm thuê có thu nhập. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/tháng. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn. Cùng vay vốn với chị còn có:
 Nguyễn Thị Hoà sinh năm 1957( Mã số: 010107050025).  , tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà.
 Hoàng Thị Xuyên sinh năm 1960 ( Mã số: 010107050023).. Chị có cửa hang tạp hoá phục vụ bà con trong thôn. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 200.000 vnđ/tháng. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư vào cửa hàng 
 Hoàng Thị D. sinh năm 1967( Mã số: 010107050022).  . Gia đình chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp. Hàng ngày chị đi chợ bán hang rau có thu nhập. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ.
 Nguyễn Thị Ánh Tuyết sinh năm 1980( Mã số: 010107050024 ).  . Chị làm nông nghiệp và đi chợ rau. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ.

loans.use: raising animals, farming

loans.name: Phirum

texts.en:
Mr. Phirum C., 38, and his wife, Mrs. Sokha Kong, 44, who live in a village about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1994 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home.

Phirum and his wife have been farming for eighteen years. They grow many types of vegetables in their farmland in the village. They sometimes sell their products in the village and sometimes sell at Chbar Ampov market, located in Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Phirum is requesting a loan of US$ 700 to use for growing vegetables.

loans.use: To use for growing vegetables

loans.name: Albertine

texts.fr: Mme W. Albertine est née en 1960 à Lomé. Mariée et mère de trois (03) enfants ; elle est coiffeuse de profession. La qualité de son travail et sa bonne maîtrise du métier lui ont toujours value une admiration exceptionnelle. Elle sollicite donc un financement pour acheter le matériel de travail afin d’attirer encore plus de clientèles et assurer une vie stable à sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Albertine W. was born in 1960 in Lomé. Married and the mother of 3 children, she is a professional hairdresser. The quality of her work and her mastery of the trade have always brought her exceptional admiration. She is therefore requesting a loan to buy necessary hairdressing implements so as to attract still more customers and insure her family of a stable life.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of necessary implements for hairdressing

loans.name: Đô Thi Thuy Group

texts.vi:
Đỗ Thị Thuỷ sinh năm 1965 ( Mã số: 010107050032). Chị hiện đang sống cùng chồng và hai con tại Văn Thượng, Xuân Canh, Đông Anh, Hà Nội. Chồng chị làm thợ xây có thu nhập theo ngày, bản than chị tăng gia sản xuất và đi chợ rau. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.000.000 vnđ /tháng. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 5.014.000 vnđ đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn và bò. Trong nhóm vay cùng chị còn có:
 Bùi Thị Điệp sinh năm 19( Mã số: 010107050034 ).  , tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn và đi chợ.
 Hoàng Thị Cúc sinh năm 1958 ( Mã số: 010107050033 ). Chị có cửa hàng ăn phục vụ bà con trong thôn. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 200.000 vnđ/tháng. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư vào cửa hàng 
 Hoàng Thị N. sinh năm 1980( Mã số: 010107050036 ).  . Gia đình chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp. Hàng ngày chị đi chợ buôn bán gà và chăn nuôi. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ.
 Hoàng Thị Lê sinh năm 1946( Mã số: 010107050027 ).  Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi gà đẻ.
 Đào Thị N. sinh năm 1976( Mã số: 010107050030 ).  Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để nuôi vịt đẻ trứng.
Nguyễn Thị Huyền sinh năm 1971 ( Mã số: 010107050035 ). Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 5.014.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi lợn, gà.
Nguyễn Thị Ngân sinh năm 1973 ( Mã số: 010107050028 ). Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 5.014.000 vnđ để đầu tư vào cửa hàng giải khát( bán bánh kẹo, bia, nước ngọt,…)

loans.use: raising arnimals

loans.name: Akou

texts.fr: Agée de 49 ans, Mme K. Akou est née à Atakpamé et a neuf (09) personnes à charge. Elle est seule à subvenir aux besoins de la famille par son commerce de produits alimentaires et articles de ménage. Souvent confrontée aux manques de moyens, elle n’arrive pas à combler l’attente de ses clients. Pour s’approvisionner en marchandises et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, elles sollicite un financement. Les bénéfices tirés de son activité lui permettront de bien prendre soin de sa famille et surtout veiller à la réussite de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Akou K., 49, was born in Atakpamé and is responsible for 9 persons. She is the sole breadwinner for her family, drawing her income from her little general store, selling groceries and household goods. Often confronted by a lack of capital, she is not able to satisfy the demand of her customers. In order to stock up on merchandise and better satisfy her clientele, she is requesting a loan. The profit from her business will allow her to take good care of her family and especially, to make sure her children succeed.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: stocking up on merchandise

loans.name: Hoang Thi Ha Group

texts.vi:
Hoàng Thị Hà sinh năm 1964. ( Mã số:010107050001). Vợ chồng chị có hai con còn nhỏ đang độ tuổi đi học. Chồng chị là công nhân có thu  nhập ổn định. Ngoài công việc đồng áng, chị còn đi chợ bán đồ ăn sẵn( giò, chả, nem,…). Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/tháng. chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có:
 Nguyễn Thị T.ềm sinh năm 1972 ( Mã số: 010107050005 ). Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ bán hang quần áo. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 250.000 vnđ.
 Đào Thị Phượng sinh năm1977, ( Mã số: 010107050004 )  Chị tham gia mức vay: 3.270.000 vnđ để mở để chăn nuôi gà đẻ trứng.
 Hoàng Thị M. sinh năm 1978, ( Mã số: 010107050006)  Chị là công nhân có thu nhập theo tháng. Chị vay vốn mức vay: 3.270.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi.
 Hoàng Thị D. sinh năm 1972 ( Mã số: 010107050003 )  ngoài chăn nuôi, chị còn trồng cây cảnh. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 250.000 vnđ/ngày. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi.
 Nguyễn Thị Hạnh sinh năm 1978 ( Mã số: 010107050002 ). Gia đình chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp. Ngoài ra chị còn chồng cây cảnh, cây ăn quả. Chị vay mức: 4.142.000 vnđ để mua giống cây trồng và cây ăn quả.

loans.use: raising animals

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Né en 1973 à Kpalimé, Mr E. Komi est revendeur des appareils frigorifiques. Marié et père de quatre (04) enfants, il a toujours fait preuve d’une bonne gestion et a gagné la confiance de sa clientèle. Pour faire régulièrement des commandes d’appareils frigorifiques et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, il sollicite un financement. De ses revenus, il pourra subvenir aux conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Born in 1973 in Kpalimé, Mr. Komi E. is a retailer of refrigeration equipment. A married man and the father of four, he has always demonstrated good management and has earned the trust of his customers. To place orders on a regular basis and to satisfy his customers, he is requesting financing. With his income, he will be able to support his family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer
